title: south western railway strike december christmas latest
story: Festive trips face being thrown into turmoil as train workers plan to walk out between December  and New Years Day, while major stations are shut for engineering works.Great Western Railway, Heathrow Express and TfL Rail services will be affected as London Paddington closes between December  and .Network Rail is planning to carry out  projects over the festive period - causing chaos for millions of passengers travelling for Christmas.Major upgrade work will also be taking place at London Kings Cross - including tunnel and structure work, drainage inspections and upgrading overhead line equipment.The majority will be carried out Christmas Day and Boxing Day - when most of the rail network is traditionally shut down.But there will also be limited trains from the station during the morning of December .Southeastern Highspeed and Eurostar trains will not stop at Ashford, Kent, between December  and .There are  per cent fewer engineers working this Christmas compared with  - hopefully meaning more lines and services will operate as normal.South Western Railway carries nearly , passengers every day from London Waterloo to regions including Sussex and Hampshire as well as to Devon and Cornwall.RMT assistant general secretary Steve Hedley told The Daily : This will be the longest nearly-continuous rail strike in British history.“We know it will cause disruption over the Christmas period, but our members have simply had enough.”UK rail strikes have been ongoing since April  due to disagreements surrounding the planned introduction of driver-only operation, not having the train guards shut the doors and it later also included pay rates and working hours.This Christmas is set to be the longest strike in the two-year dispute at any rail operator as the past the iest walkouts lasted three days.In , a nine-day strike happened after the government announced plans to reduce pay during the First World War.The government caved after nine days and agreed to maintain wags for another year and it resulted in the standardisation of wages across rail companies and the introduction of maximum eight hour day.Network Rail chief executive Andrew Haines said: Our passengers want and deserve a more reliable railway and thats why this Christmas we are out working on the track and behind the scenes to help make that happen.Signicantly fewer people travel over the Christmas holidays, which is why we do so much work at this time of year.But we know some of our passengers will have important plans, so please check before you travel. We have plenty of people in our stations in the run up to and over the break who are on hand to help.In addition to the engineering works, Members of the Rail, Maritime and Transport union will walk out for  days in a long-running dispute over guards on trains.The strikes will take place from : on Monday December  until : on Wednesday December , from : on Friday December  until : on Tuesday December , and from : on Friday December  until : on January .Multiple major upgrade works at London King’s Cross:More to follow...For the latest news on this story keep checking back at Sun Online.Download our fantastic, new and improved free App for the best ever Sun Online experience. title: apprentice bbc box ticking
story: Nothing, except the words “TO THE RIVER” and a dirty great arrow, written on to a wall, about a metre from their heads.So they pause for a few seconds, look around, then scamper off in completely the wrong direction.The tip of the stupidity iceberg, as it transpired, on last week’s episode of The Apprentice, where they’ve been delivering this sort of comedy gold for  series now and, for about  of them, have had to put up with people assuring us: “It’s past its sell-by date.”One year they’ll be right, as well.But not this one, which has thrown up another wonderful selection of candidates with a whole iety of ­personality flaws and business skills, ranging from the competent, Flump-voiced Iasha ­Masood, right the way down to Ryan-Mark Parsons, the camp Michael McIntyre clone who Lord Sugar correctly labelled “a weather cock”. Evenwe can argue about the “weather” bit.Two contestants, though, go straight into the all-time Apprentice Hall Of Fame, alongside the greats like Paul Torrisi and Stuart Baggs.First is Cockney barrow boy Thomas Skinner, who sticks out among the boys like Ray Winstone in a touring production of Priscilla, Queen Of The Desert, and has turned out to be a lot more likeable than I was expecting.The second, though, most certainly hasn’t. For she is Lottie Lion, the librarian and wine snob who’s given to quoting Shakespeare: “For though she is but little she is a massive pain in the a**e.” Or words to that effect.All your worst office nightmares rolled into one, this girl. An undermining, ­passive-aggressive crawler who can swivel on a sixpence, depending on which way Lord Sugar’s wind is blowing.“In business there is no room for ­gambling.” “Hang on. Business is a gamble. You don’t take risks, you get nowhere.” “Yes, risk-taking is important, Lord Sugar.”Lottie’s also not helped by the fact she’s often right and most certainly wasn’t to blame for the failure of the scavenger hunt task which disintegrated, in ­shameful fashion, right at the start when team Empower’s Pamela Laird asked: “Does anyone know when the Second World War started ” Silence. They didn’t know when it started, ­finished, or even what side was responsible for killing Biggie and Tupac.A media meltdown followed, yet, amid the general despair, no one bothered to thank The Apprentice for the public ­service of flagging up this ignorance, because that’s not what happens with this show. Instead, it gets accused of stuff.This year, inevitably, it’s been called racist and claims have been made that the first four candidates were sacked due to their skin colour, rather than the fact they were completely useless or ­produced a “bespoke ­corporate ­lollipop” that looked more like a vibrator.It’s only Twitter that’s saying these things, of course, but they need to be quashed as the BBC is actually dumb enough to listen to these imbeciles and forget Sugar’s first winner was Tim Campbell and his show is about the only place on the network where black and minority ethnic people will be treated entirely on their merits.Get rid of The Apprentice and, I guarantee you, its ­precious and entertaining hours will be filled with the same mollycoddling, box-ticking, ­condescending, right-on ­b*****ks that fills most of the rest of the Beeb’s output.Treasure this show while you still can .The One Show, Matt Baker: “I’m very much looking forward to talking about your play, Meera [Syal].”The X Factor: Celebrity, Louis Walsh to Jenny Ryan: “Very few people can sing Shirley Bassey but you nailed every single note.”With a Black  Decker staple gun and no anaesthetic.ONLY two places there’s ever likely to be a demand for Vinnie Jones to sing Lip Up Fatty, by Bad Manners.One of them is Piers Morgan’s Hollywood wake.Thankfully, that’s probably still a good  or  months away.So I’ll stick with the other, X Factor: Celebrity, where we were already several horrors into the night when Martin Bashir’s brain developed technical issues, just as he was about to assault the second verse of EasyLike Sunday Morning.“I’ve forgotten the words . . .“A wah wah-waaah wanna be freeeee.“I do apologise.”Not necessary, Martin.Vinnie’s manic can-can took the initial sting out of things a couple of turns later.And, when it came to the climax, Simon Cowell dodged his decision and the public voted-off Jonny Labey and Victoria Ekanoye instead of a startled Bashir, who gasped: “What has happened ”You stayed silent. They sang. Go figure.Seven Worlds, One Planet cutting and pasting that horrendous old footage of the sky-ing walruses.A BBC continuity woman deciding His Dark Materials is our “new Sunday night obsession”. .The slyly partisan One Show featuring a film with Corbynista Ken Loach calling for “real change”, on the day the election was called.And arch-luvvie David Tennant describing the responsibility of murdering one Proclaimers song for Children In Need: Got It Covered as: “A bit like National Service.”For you or the viewers, David THE guessing games begin as soon as the opening credits for BBC’s big new Sunday night drama kick in and reveal it’s set in a parallel universe.A place where relationships between humans and their animal soul-mates are unusually close.Swindon “Oxford.”Oooh, close, but no cigar at the start of His Dark Materials, an epic, eight-part adaptation of author Philip Pullman’s trilogy that’ll probably go down well with anyone who’s read the books and loves fantasy adventure.Unfortunately, I haven’t read the books and hate fantasy adventure.My loss, I realise. It means I draw an emotional blank with the show’s incredible production valuesand even Ruth Wilson’s fabulous performance as Mrs Coulter.Initial stumbling block is the fact everyone’s trailed around by their own soul in animal form, Daemons who can all talk but never once stop to take a dump or cock their leg against the scenery.Teenage heroine Lyra has a shape-shting weasel thing called Pantalaimon, James “Asriel” McAvoy’s got Stelmaria the snow leopard and John Torode’s got a hairless gastropod called Gregg. But that’s another show, I think.On this one, there’s also the all-powerful Magisterium, giving everyone the creeps, and the uncharted north’s mysterious city in the sky, which James McAvoy is getting quite excited about.The detail that finished off His Dark Materials for me, though, was the news that arrived just before the climax of episode one.“Roger’s been taken by the Gobblers.”As the late, great Eric Morecambe once said, there really is no answer to that.Would it be fair to assume the BBC’s bisexual Dracula bats for both sides BBC’s darkly funny Guilt, with Mark Bonnar and Jamie Sives.The nightmarish, bird-eating Iranian viper footage on Seven Worlds One Planet.Lee Mack pretending to be Anneka Rice’s nude le model on the outstanding Would I Lie To You .C’s brilliant Celebrity Hunted climaxing with the question: “Is Gavin Henson really stupid enough to go back to his own house ” .And best ever breakfast TV host, Piers Morgan, marking his eagerly awaitedto Good Morning Britain by identying singer Ruby Turner as the rhyming slang for curry, “Ruby Murray”.Food food food, Piers.Clinton Morrison: “I think Mesut Ozil had a prove to point.”Jeff Stelling: “For United this is a matter of extreme danger with a capital X.”Tipping Point, Ben Shephard: “Piglet and Eeyore are companions of which fictional bear ”Matt: “Donkey.”The Chase, Bradley Walsh: “Pemberton Place in Atlanta is named after the inventor of what soft drink ”Glynis: “Orange.”Bradley Walsh: “Which cabinet designer ­published a book of his own designs in  ”Vivien: “Mr Ikea.”And Bradley Walsh: “Dingoes are said to have been introduced to Australia by whom ”Kirsten: “The Kennel Club.”SO what’s it like in the non-stop Mardi Gras of ­EastEnders at the moment Callum: “I’ve been thinking of taking an ­embalming course.”CHILDREN In Need: Got It Covered.My ears: Got ’em covered.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: labour brexit election nationalisation
story: Households across the UK could suffer average losses of nearly £, each from pensions and savingsLabour’s zealots were to pay below market value for the companies, according to economists.Eventhey paid a fair price, Labour would mortgage the future of younger generations to meet the eye-watering £billion-plus cost of taking the companies back into state ownership.And for what  To suit the ideological posturing of Corbyn and his fellow extremist John McDonnell.It’s not asthe railways or the energy companies would be better run. Just ask anyone old enough to remember British Rail.While dinosaurs Corbyn and McDonnell play fantasy politics, aspirational young working class voters have more realistic priorities. Such as wanting reductions in income tax and stamp duty.There is so much more at stake in this general election than just the threat Labour poses to Brexit.DOES anyone know what Labour’s position on Brexit is Jeremy Corbyn claims to have told his squabbling shadow cabinet to fall in behind him and toe the party line.Whether Corbyn will let the voters know what that agreed position is before the election is another matter.Given Labour fought the last election promising to respect the referendum result and has done everything possible since to thwart it, we doubt it.It is suggested Labour would try to renegotiate with the EU for a closer trading partnership , then hold another referendum.What they would do about the inevitable deadlock is anyone’s guess. Meanwhile, several Labour front-benchers have suggested they would campaign for Remain.One union leader has branded them “ludicrous”. Lada affects a very signicant number of people — it is three times more prevalent than type  diabetes in adults.Studies suggest between one per cent and two per cent of the UK population will develop it.Patients with Lada are often not well managed because they are misdiagnosed as type  — I see a lot of agitated patients who are really struggling to manage their blood sugar levels despite following medical advice.Professor Olov Rolandsson, a world-leading expert in Lada and diabetes researcher at Umea University in Sweden, also told the newspaper that people are missing out on the right treatment, which raises the risk of complications including heart disease and eye problems.Diabetes is a condition where someone has too much glucose – a type of sugar – in their blood.When people don’t have diabetes their blood sugar levels are controlled by insulin produced in their pancreas.If someone has diabetes, they’re either not producing insulin, or the insulin they do produce can’t work properly or there isn’t enough of it.This means that sugar builds up in their blood and can’t get into the cells of their body where it’s used for fuel.Type , is an autoimmune disease, which develops when the insulin-producing cells in the pancreas have been destroyed and the body is unable to produce it.Its treated by injecting insulin or using a pump multiple times a day.Type , the most common form of the condition, is when the body doesnt make enough insulin or the insulin it makes doesnt work properly.Some people can manage it with a healthy diet, regular physical activity and,they need to, by losing weight.But the longer someone has type , the more likely it is that they will need medication.Type . shares characteristics of both and, earlier this year, the World Health Organisation recognised it as a hybrid form of diabetes.As of yet, the cause of Lada is unknown but experts think that some genes might put people at higher risk.Unlike being overweight - a major risk factor for type  - people with Lada tend to be a healthy weight.Patients are usually diagnosed between the ages of  and  - older than typical for type  but relatively young for type .The symptoms are the same as both kinds of diabetes:Symptoms generally come on much slower than they do with type  - over months rather than weeks - but are more obvious and quicker than type .There isnt yet a definite, agreed way of treating Lada but research by Action Lada is looking into how common it is and how best to look after it.Until this study shares its findings, most healthcare professionals agree that the aim of treatment is to keep insulin being produced for as long as possible.So it’s recommended that insulin treatment is started early.Diabetes UK says its receiving a growing number of enquiries about the condition.The symptoms tend to come on more slowly than type  diabetes but are usually more obvious than would be expected in type  diabetes.“There is ongoing research looking at She told the court she deferred the application indefinitely because the couple wanted a young under-three years old, simple needs child.Ms Loades claimed the council had a lot of older vulnerable children who needed placing for adoption so she told Mr and Mrs Manders to come back another time.The court was told social worker Shirley Popat visited the couple’s five-bed home in Maidenhead to assess them. But in a  phone call she “confirmed she would not accept our application due to our cultural heritage and our only other option was to adopt from India or Pakistan, Mrs Mander said.Recalling a phone conversation between her husband and the social worker, Mrs Mander added: I could hear from his voice that something wasn’t right.I heard something about cultural heritage,” a smartly-dressed Mrs Mander told the court. title: john legend politically correct airbrushing
story: Why  Because last year, the original song was banned by a radio station in the US state of Ohio after “listeners”complained that it’s a socially unacceptable ditty promoting coercive behaviour.So it’s now been fed in to the #MeToo sausage machine and emerged as a smooth cylinder of PC compliance where, among other lyric changes, Legend and his duet partner Kelly Clarkson substitute “Say, what’s in this drink  ” for “If I have one more drink  ”.According to the songwriter Frank Loesser’s son John: “It was a flirtatious, wonderful, sexy number between two people who like each other. It really wasn’t anything but that.”But at the time of the ban, Cleveland Rape Crisis Center president and CEO Sondra Miller said: “It really pushed the line of consent.The character in the song is saying ‘no’, and they’re saying, ‘Well, does no really mean yes ’. “What we know is consent is ‘yes’ andyou get a ‘no’, it means ‘no’ and you should stop right there.”Let’s hope she’s never listening to the radio when Fire by The Pointer Sisters comes on. “You’re pullin’ me close, I just say no, I say I don’t like it, but you know I’m a liar.”Then, next verse: “You’re takin’ me home, you say you want to stay, I say I want to be alone . . . but you know I’m a liar.”Is she a “liar” who’s simply pretending she doesn’t have the hots for him when secretly she does  Or is she a victim being coerced into thinking that about herself by a controlling lover Discuss. While we still can. Or what about the Rolling Stones classic Under My Thumb, about a girl “who once pushed me around” but now, “It’s a squirmin’ dog who’s just had her day, Under my thumb, A girl who has just changed her ways” Far better, surely, to put it all out there so our kids can learn the vital le skill of rational and informed debate.A rock ’n’ roll twist, perhaps, on the premise of Shakespeare’s The Taming Of The Shrew, in which Petruchio uses a number of tactics to bring his we Katherina to heel — or is that now banned too In today’s “attention economy”, keyboard warriors desperate to be heard appear to be scouring the airwaves for even the merest whf of potential offence and, worse still, some are seeing their confected high dudgeon rewarded with a ban.And it’s not just the music industry having its chain yanked. This week it emerged that several theatres will be dropping the traditional “Ladies and gentlemen, please take your seats,” instruction to avoid offending any transgender customers.Sigh. Of all the things in the world to truly feel offended by, is this really a priority  Even Barack Obama, the darling of the liberal classes, feels that the call-out culture sometimes goes too far.“The world is messy. There are ambiguities,” said the former US President during a recent interview about youth activism. This idea of purity and you’re never compromised and you’re always politically ‘woke’ and all that stuff . . . you should get over that quickly.”He went on to address the “cancel culture” on social media where someone who has said or done something to which others object is immediately shut down in a wave of judgmental condemnation.“That’s not activism. That’s not bringing about change,” he added. “If all you’re doing is casting stones, you’re probably not going to get that far. That’s easy to do.”Hear hear. So, by all means, write new songs through the prism of #MeTooyou so wish. But banning or airbrushing the classics to suit modern sensitivitiesdoes us all a disservice.Far better, surely, to put it all out there so our kids can learn the vital le skill of rational and informed debate.“Jo Swinson: Britain’s Next Prime Minister”is the headline on just one of the many missives – a six-page, A booklet.Under Electoral Commission rules, each party can spend up to £, for each constituency it contests.She must be nearing that on my house alone.IRON Maiden frontman Bruce Dickinson has split from we Paddy after  years and moved in with a “superfan”.Bruce, , who has an estimated fortune of £million, is now shacked up in Paris with Leana Dolci, who has followed his band for ten years and recently attended a heavy-metal festival in a T-shirt that read: “I fancy the lead singer.” Subtle.When plugging his autobiography a couple of years ago, Bruce told an interviewer he tried to keep his private le out of the public gaze.“So I made the decision that, in amongst not being horrid to people . . . I also don’t want to tell confidences about other people’s lives,” he said.Bruce can only hope his estranged we shares the same view.THIS Halloween, famous fancy dress supplier Smfys boasted on its website, “Looking hot has never been so easy,” while offering a range of saucy outfits from devil cheerleader to Miss Whiplash and sexy skeleton.In my twenties, it was an old bedsheet with a couple of eye-holes. But there are a few purists out there who eschew the sexy-not-scary look and embrace the original Halloween’s wholly spooky, otherworldly intentions.Believe it or not, this hideous creature is model Heidi Klum arriving at her own Halloween party in New York . . . with all the confidence of a woman who knows full well that, next morning, she s to being an effortlessly sexy beauty with or without sartorial assistance.REMEMBER James Stunt When he was married to Bernie Ecclestone’s daughter Petra, he used a fleet of luxury cars to make ostentatiously expensive purchases at ious designer stores and art galleries.But Stunt has insisted he would never deceive the Prince of Wales because, “he’s a great man. I consider him to be a friend”.Whether the feeling is mutual one can only speculate. But something tells me Mr Stunt is about to be royally ghosted.THE imagined target voter for the Tories in the General Election is “Workington Man”.He joins Tony Blair’s “Mondeo Man” , David Cameron’s “Holby City Woman”and Margaret Thatcher’s “Essex Man” as a confection of election strategists, who would like us all to think they’re experts but, in truth, know as much as the rest of usabout what the outcome will be.Many moons ago, when I worked for a dferent newspaper, staff were taken on a drink think-tank where a “creative” from a top ad agency wielded a cardboard cutout of “Swindon Woman” who he’d laughably concluded was our typical reader.There was much derision all round, particularly when she disappeared and was later found being cuddled in the bed of a comatose sports reporter.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: tory poll lead starmer interview
story: As Prime Minister Boris Johnson prepared to set out the Tories’ strategy with a clear thumbs-up from No, Sir Keir could only stumble over his own stance.His cringeworthy quiz on live TV came as his party pledged to renegotiate the Brexit deal in just three months — then put it to the public in another referendum.Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn added to the turmoil by refusing to rule out cancelling Brexit.He left the door open to revoking Article  —that’s the price of being propped up by the Lib Dems after the election.  And he hinted that Labour could keep free movement after Brexit — a move that will infuriate Leave voters in his party’s heartlands.At the start of a torrid day for Labour, Sir Keir was skewered on ITV’s Good Morning Britain show. Presenter Susanna Reid asked the Shadow Cabinet minister five times how Labour would campaign in a second referendum.Unable to give a straight answer, he blustered: “Well, in a sense, what I campaign for is secondary because what we are saying is that it is for the country to decide.  We’re saying less power to politicians, that’s where we have been struck for the last ½ years.”Ms Reid asked him againLabour wanted Britain to leave the EU or remain. An almost incoherent Sir Keir muttered: “The Labour party says we are going to put this choice, before you.”He also revealed that while he will be in charge of Labour’s bid to renegotiate Brexit, he has already ruled out voting for the deal in a second referendum. Instead he wants Britain to Remain. But challenged on this bizarre stance, the rattled frontbencher said: “That is missing the point.”Sir Keir went on to say the EU’s Customs Union would have to be “reconfigured” because it only allows Member States to set the negotiating mandates for free trade agreements .Labour wants to rip up the rules so the UK can negotiate FTAs “in conjunction” with the bloc. But EU diplomats warned there was “not much” the bloc could do to involve Britain in shaping its trade policy other than drawing up a “consultation” role.And in a major blow to Mr Corbyn’s election hopes, outgoing Brussels boss Jean-Claude Juncker last night panned Labour’s vision. Speaking about Mr Corbyn’s plan to negotiate a new deal with the EU and then put it to a second referendum, Mr Juncker told the BBC: “Honestly spoken, I don’t think that this is a realistic approach.”But the Labour boss defended the policy, insisting his party can negotiate a brand new agreement with the EU in less than three months.He said: “Keir and I have spent many, many hours in Brussels and other European capitals. We wouldn’t be saying thiswe didn’t think it was realistic and do-able.”But Mr Juncker wasn’t the only senior EU official to dismiss the idea. One senior source said Mr Corbyn’s strategy was “not credible” and “delusional”.Another admitted that rewriting the PM’s deal to include a closer relationship would be “easy” to achieve within three months, but added: “Less straightforward is what the UK may ask on EU trade policy.”KEIR STARMER: You get a referendum...you get the choice between the best deal that can be secured...or Remain.SR: And what are you going to campaign for in that second referendum KS: What I campaign for is secondary...SR: Hang on, hang on, I need to know what you believe in  Do you think we should leave or remain KS: The Labour party says we are going to put this choice, before you.SR: But I am voting for you...Do you want to leave or remain KS: The Labour party says we are going to put this choice, before you. I’ve said many times what my personal position is.SR: You want to remain.KS: The Labour party says we are going to put this choice, before you. But that is missing the point.SR: So I am voting to stay in the EU...Are we leaving or remaining KS: The Labour party says we are going to put this choice, before you. We are going to, within six months, have a referendum and we are going to say here is the best deal that can be secured and it is going to go up against Remain and we are going to let the public decide.SR: It will be such a good deal that you yourself will vote against it KS: Well we are duty bound to get the best deal…SR: But how can it be a really good dealyou are going to vote against it After Sir Keir’s sloppy interview, he and Mr Corbyn travelled to the swing seat of Harlow, Essex, to insist Labour’s contorted Brexit position was in fact “very simple”.But Mr Corbyn refused to rule out reversing the EU referendum result altogetherthat helps him get the keys to No.He said: “All I can say is we are campaigning to win this election with a majority Labour government. We are not campaigning to form a coalition with anybody. We’re campaigning to go into office to carry out our manesto and that’s exactly what we’re going to be doing for the next five weeks in this election campaign.”Lib Dem boss Jo Swinson has already “ruled out” a deal to put Mr Corbyn in Downing Street. But former Labour MP Chuka Umunna — now a Lib Dem — hinted a back-room arrangement may be possibleLabour ditches its leader.He added: “The two main parties in their current configuration are not fit for purpose.”“The Labour Party can’t deliver that change and are a vote for the opposite — more delay and uncertainty. They won’t rule out revoking Article  altogether and want unlimited immigration, which would put pressure on our NHS.”In another stump speech, Mr Corbyn will insist the December  election is not about him, as he sets out his stall to be PM. story: Anyone who realised that the organisation for which they work is awash with cash would do the same.When Ahmed realised that she was receiving only £ for presenting her -minute long BBC programme when Jeremy Vine was being paid £, for his show of the same , she thought, not unreasonably, “I want a bit of that”.Like any other employee, she has every right to use the employment tribunal system to settle grievances. Yet the way Ahmed’s case has been pumped up as a great cause celebre for women is frankly ridiculous.The real scandal is not that a highly paid female BBC presenter has been paid less than a male one. It is that the BBC is lavishing such fat pay on any of them while pleading poverty and ending free TV licences for people over .Ahmed’s case for equal pay is very weak. It is based on the argument that presenting Newswatch — which holds BBC’s news programmes to account — is of equal value to presenting Vine’s old show, Points Of View, which invited comments from the public on a wide iety of BBC programmes.The BBC claims the disparity is down to the fact that Points Of View is classied as entertainment while Newswatch comes under news.  Surely a more direct comparison would be between what Ahmed is paid and what her male predecessor, Raymond Snoddy, was paid.She received the same as he did. How is that gender discrimination   But while the BBC might have a strong defence in Ahmed’s case, it doesn’t endear the corporation to me.Every time the BBC Charter comes up for renewal, it poses as a terribly worthy public ­service broadcaster putting out serious, educational programmes no commercial broadcaster would touch.Unless the Government allows it to jack up the licence fee, it argues, it will mean no more David Attenborough, no more news correspondents in Mogadishu.Then, as soon as the BBC Charter is renewed, it goes back to pumping out the same old entertainment shows, many of them indistinguishable from commercial TV.A genuine public service broadcaster would not pay Gary Lineker £.million a year, Graham Norton £,or Huw Edwards £,.Compared with the fattest of BBC fat cats, Samira Ahmed might well feel undervalued. Yet earning £ for presenting a -minute programme would be a dream for many TV licence-payers, many of whom do not even earn that amount of money in a week.The BBC is merciless in its efforts to collect what is really a tax on TV ownership. Unlike other unpaid utility bills, failing to buy a TV licence is a criminal offence, leading to low-paid people struggling with finances being dragged through the courts.Last year, , people were prosecuted for non-payment. By the way,  per cent of them were women — possibly because they were more likely to be at home during the day when TV licence enforcement officers tend to call. That is the real gender unfairness, not highly paid female BBC presenters receiving less money than male presenters.Ahmed’s case has highlighted the old boys’ world from which the BBC hires its presenters.  Vine, she claims, was “gted” his Radio  show without any proper recruitment process. BBC management then allowed his agent to jack up his salary.The BBC seems to see itself as immune from the pay restraint where in the public sector. When David Cameron became Prime Minister, he said any public body would need an extremely good excuse to pay anyone more than the £, a year he then earned.Yet the BBC’s accounts for   show it paid  “on-air talent” salaries in excess of this figure.  While there have been token reductions for some male ­presenters, such as the now- retired John Humphrys, many have seen salary increases.High pay doesn’t end with the presenters. There were also  BBC managers and executives who were paid more than the PM last year.  If the BBC wants to justy the TV licence, it needs to be cutting excessive pay among its board and ­presenters.If it wants to be a commercial station, on the other hand, it should give up the licence fee and find funding from subscriptions and ­advertising.  Then it wouldn’t be our business how much its executives and presenters were paid because their salaries would come out of the pockets only of people who chose to subscribe to its programmes.This is particularly important now, in the week that both Boris Johnson and Jeremy Corbyn have vowed to sort out the threat of over-s losing their licence fee exemption.As it becomes an urgent election issue, the worst look for the BBC is to be seen throwing money at presenters rather than the people it needs most — its loyal viewers.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: mum sprays breast milk dirtybird festival
story: Wearing just a black swimming costume and pink boots, the blonde was filmed grinding to EDM at a festival in Southern Calornia last month.Seemingly intent on proving her party-loving days are not behind her, the new mum pulled aside her skimpy swimsuit to flash her breast.But she then shocked her fellow ravers when she apparently started to squirt her own breast milk at crowds “like a super soaker”.One reveller screamed in surprise and another yelled “oh s**t”.Another female raver at Dirtybird Campout shouted out “how is she doing that ”Undeterred by the mixed reviews, the new mum continued dancing and spraying the crowds.Another woman showed her support by kneeling down in front of the blonde mum and trying to catch a few drops of her milk in her mouth.The strange video was captured by festival-goer Eric Falconi, who had thought he had “seen it all” at a rave.He tweeted: “[Dirtybird Campout] you never disappoint. S**t got pretty weird.”One person said: “Yooooo breast milk is like f****ng gold and she’s just squirting out like it’s water ”Another added: “Yeah ravers are weird and it’s confirmed now.”An EDM events account replied saying: “The breast milk is not a big deal, her squirting it like a super soaker is.” Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: jeremy corbyn labour party election five eyes
story: Senior Whitehall insiders say the flow information Britain receives from the “Five Eyes” alliance would dry up because of a lack of trust in the Labour leader.Five Eyes is one of the most extensive espionage alliances in history.Currently, the alliance also includes the United States, Australia, Canada and New Zealand.Former foreign secretary Jack Straw said that other countries could “lessen intelligence co-operation with us”Corbyn wins the election, reported The Times.Although Labour leftwingers would see it as an establishment plot, he told The Times: “This would not be any ‘deep-state conspiracy’, but the human reaction of people who give their careers to keep us safe, some-times at serious personal risk to their own lives.”One former permanent secretary with close links to the intelligence services said: “It would have a chilling effect. That would put us at greater risk.“The Americans would be very wary indeed about having the same broad confidence in intelligence sharing.”The concerns stem from Corbyns perceived support for anti-West states and his opposition to Trident.Back in April, Corbyn was branded a danger to Britain after signalling he would scrap Trident in a car-crash interview with Andrew Marr.Corbyn went against his party’s official position by saying he was not sure a promise to renew Trident nukes would be in Labour’s election manesto.Several former defence chiefs, Labour cabinet ministers and high-ranking diplomats have since expressed their concerns over Labour moving to  Downing Street.The former defence secretary Lord Hutton of Furness confirmed that a Corbyn premiership would “place a major question mark over the continued operation of a vital source of intelligence.”He said: “It’s impossible to look at it with anything other than extreme alarm.His views on Nato, his anti-Americanism, his failure to support any single British military expedition since he came into parliament, his opposition to nuclear weapons and his support for Putin’s Russia — his world view is completely at odds with every postwar Labour leader.”Whitehall sources have also claimed that Labour leader’s director of strategy Seamus Milne could be banned from seeing the most sensitive intelligenceCorbyn wins the election.It comes as Corbyn suffered a major blow as Brussels blasted his “delusional” plan to renegotiate Boris Johnson’s deal and secure a say over EU trade talks.EU officials and diplomats told The Sun that Labour’s bid to rip up the rules of the Customs Union so the UK can negotiate FTAs “in conjunction” with the bloc would meet fierce opposition.But one EU source warned: “Less straightforward is what the UK may ask on EU trade policy. The first thing would be a UK request for an extension, with a justication for that.”Another added that Corbyn’s strategy was “not credible” and “as delusional” as Boris Johnson’s pledge to negotiate a trade deal before the end of December .

title: one in twenty british adults never retire
story: And one in  of those who believe retirement is on the cards reckon they’ll be aged  or older when the time comes.But not all employees want to hang up their hat, as  per cent say they wouldn’t be able to afford to stop working and  per cent claim they would be bored.One quarter of adults would like to keep their brain sharp, and  per cent feel work gives them a sense of purpose, according to a study of , office workers.Other popular reasons for wanting to continue the nine to five include enjoying colleagues’ company and conversation every day, and getting a rewarding feeling from their work.The thought of spending all day with their partner, having to watch daytime TV and paying more for heating bills are other reasons Brits want to remain employed.Geoffrey Dennis, chief executive of SPANA, which provides free veterinary treatment to working animals in developing countries, said: “Most adults in the UK would like to retire early.But many people feel they’ll be working for many more years than they’d hoped – perhaps well into their seventies, or beyond.“However, it’s clear many people also get a real sense of satisfaction going to work, as it gives them a reason to get up in the morning and a sense of purpose.Some  per cent of employees are convinced they’d feel oldthey retired, and  per cent want to keep going as it keeps their body healthy.One in  adults are proud of their position at work, while  per cent enjoy the structure of their day and eight per cent enjoy the socialising that comes with being part of a business.The study found  per cent intend to carry on working for as long as they are able to.And  per cent believethey stopped their current career they’d probably always have a part-time job or continue to work on an ad hoc basis.Only three in  adults say they’re likely to give up work suddenly, with most assuming they’ll make the transition from full time worker to retiree over a longer period of time.And although many cite money as being the factor that will have the biggest impact on when they retire ,  per cent are likely to be led by the state of their health.Others say they’ll make their decision about retirement age based on availability of work, new ambitions or general happiness levels.But to retire comfortably, most people feel they would need a pension pot of some £, for things to be manageable, and almost eight in  worry they’ll never have enough money to stop working.For those who believe retirement is a possibility, more than half of adults are looking forward to having more spare time and  per cent will welcome a stress-free lestyle.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: armistice day remembrance sunday
story: Here we explain the history behind this important day of remembrance and how it dfers from Remembrance Sunday.Armistice Day remembers the agreement between the Allies and Germany on November , , to stop fighting which marked victory for the Allies and defeat for Germany.It was signed in Compiegne in Northern France and came into effect at am.The armistice forced the Germans to evacuate invaded countries and territories within two weeks.They also had to surrender a signicant amount of war material, including five thousand guns, , machine guns, , planes.Germany, exhausted by war and with a nation of hungry citizens, reluctantly accepted the terms.Although hostilities continued in some areas, the armistice essentially brought an end to fours years of fighting in the First World War.Armistice Day and Remembrance Sunday are not the same thing.However, Armistice day is also referred to as Remembrance Day - which can be confusing.Armistice day is always on November .Remembrance Sunday is always on the second Sunday in November, but the date will change yearly - this year its on November  .A two-minute silence is often acknowledged at schools, offices and churches around the country.A National Service of Remembrance is held at The Cenotaph in Whitehall in London.Members of the Royal Family and the Government attend the service alongside representatives from the Armed Forces and the public.Another two-minute silence is held at am before a number of wreaths are laid down.The Royal Marines buglers usually sound The Last Post.A number of veterans also take part in a march past The Cenotaph.In the run up to Armistice Day and Remembrance Sunday, you will often spot veterans selling poppies at a number of locations across the country.The reason poppies are used is because they are the flowers which grew on the battlefields after the First World War ended.Poppies are also used to raise money for servicemen and women who are still alive but whose lives have been changed by war.The charity that runs the Poppy Appeal is called The Royal British Legion.The silence is meant to be time for people to remember those who lost their lives fighting for their country.According to reports, in a letter published in the London Evening News on  May , an Australian journalist, Edward George Honey, had proposed a respectful silence to remember those who had given their lives in the First World War.  Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: brussels blast corbyn brexit deal
story: EU officials and diplomats told The Sun that Labour’s bid to rip up the rules of the Customs Union so the UK can negotiate FTAs “in conjunction” with the bloc would meet fierce opposition.They said rewriting the PM’s deal to “adopt a UK mandate with higher ambition”, such as alignment on workers’ rights and the environment, would be “easy” to achieve within three months.But one EU source warned: “Less straightforward is what the UK may ask on EU trade policy. The first thing would be a UK request for an extension, with a justication for that.”Another added that Mr Corbyn’s strategy was “not credible” and “as delusional” as Boris Johnson’s pledge to negotiate a trade deal before the end of December .Shadow Brexit Secretary Keir Starmer said the Customs Union would have to be “reconfigured” because currently it only allows Member States to set the EU’s negotiating mandates for FTAs.He said this “one and ” setup would allow Britain to benefit from Brussels’ clout and that the two sides would do deals with the rest of the world “together”.EU diplomats warned there was “not much” the bloc could do to involve Britain in shaping its trade policy other than drawing up a “consultation” role.One said: “You can’t have a customs union and still expect some leeway to enter into deals with third countries. It’s impossible.”But another added: “The UK, with such an important market, would be in a position to claim a substantial role on those deals that directly affect it.”Mr Corbyn defended the policy yesterday, insisting that his party can negotiate a brand new agreement with the bloc in less than three months.Sir Keir also dismayed Brussels by immediately announcing Labour would campaign against any deal it secures in a second referendum.

title: 5 helpful announcements tory ministers
story: NewsAnalysis helpful announcements Tory ministers just happened to drop before the electionTonight is the cut off for official government announcements before the election campaign starts - but there have been plenty of baubles hung on the tree just before the deadlineShareCommentsByMikey SmithPolitical Correspondent:,  NOV NewsAnalysis "Get the biggest politics stories by emailSubscribe We will use your email address only for sending you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailGovernment departments are officially put on hold from midnight tonight, as MPs head out for six weeks of campaigning ahead of the general election. During this period - known as apospurdahapos - departments are not allowed to announce new policies or funding commitments. The rule is there to stop the party in government having an unfair advantage and using public money to campaign.But the rules donapost kick in until tonight - and thereaposs been a few announcements and communications in recent days that have been a little conveniently timed.Hereaposs a few of them. At least  Facebook adverts promising up to £ million investment in key swing seats across the UK went live last Tuesday - the day the  General Election  was announced.They are part of My Town, a Government-backed campaign that seeks residents’ views on how to improve their towns. The adverts ran without a political disclaimer, and were taken down by Facebook shortly after .pm on Friday evening.They targeted voters in marginal seats, such as Newcastle-under-Lyme, which has a  Labour  majority of just  votes. Other towns where the Facebook ads appeared included Northampton, Milton Keynes and Mansfield - which had majorities of less than ,in the  general election.  Ministers boasted this week that the hated benefits freeze would come to an end next year. Of course they didnapost mention that it was always supposed to end next year anyway. Frank Field, chairman of the Commons Work and Pensions Committee, said the .% rise in payments from April will not make up for the years of biting austerity. Instead Mr Field said his committee has demanded a higher .% rise with sustained above-inflation rises for four years. He said: “A huge chunk has been gouged out of people’s incomes, and the Government’s plans simply won’t plug the gaps that are left.” Yesterday the Housing department revealed plans to hand councils a pot of £ million to deal with "criminal " landlords.But itaposs not new money. In fact, itaposs not even a new policy. Itaposs an extension of a programme that was launched last year. That said, it did give ministers the opportunity to be seen to be doing something on a key Labour campaign issue in government time.  The Business department issued a release trumpeting £ million in new funding for schemes to boost productivity for small businesses. Itaposs mostly to pay for ious leadership and technology training programmes for firms. While theyaposve re-announced the funding to coincide with a report theyaposve produced on how businesses can become more productive, itaposs by no means new money. In fact, it was announced more than a year ago, in the  budget.  Home Secretary Priti Patel announced over the weekend she was considering giving police powers to arrest trespassers who set up unauthorised caravan sites and seize their property. Ms Patel is very keen to appear tough on law and order - and how better to do that than by cracking down on a community who historically donapost tend to vote and are a nuisance to landowners, who do tend to vote BONUS: Boris Johnsonaposs letter to Jeremy CorbynPrime Ministers arenapost supposed to use Number  for political purposes. Thataposs why PMs take photos with new party appointees on the street outside, and why they take the crest off the lectern when they call an election.

title: moving hand written signs pop
story: NewsGeneral election: Moving handwritten Tory Story signs pop up across UKThey have been putting up notices and posting pictures with the hashtag #TorystoryShareCommentsByNicola BartlettPolitical Correspondent:,  NOV Updated:,  NOV News"Get the biggest politics stories by emailSubscribe We will use your email address only for sending you newsletters. The staff are so overworked, trying to care for  patients with  qualied nurses. The NHS canapost survive for another  years of this Tory government.Vote Labour on December th to save the NHS.Broken respiratorIn  I gave birth to my daughter. To end the cuts and save the NHS vote Labour on th December.

The Toriesapos chairman has been monstered on ITVaposs Good Morning Britain for releasing a doctored video - of someone, er, being aposmonsteredapos on ITVaposs Good Morning Britain.James Cleverly was savaged by host Piers Morgan for cynically editing footage of Labour on the previous dayaposs edition of the breakfast TV show.In a car crash interview, Mr Cleverly spent more than  minutes trying to pretend a fake news lie of Keir Starmer talking about Brexit was not doctored, when it clearly was to anyone who has eyes.In the end he tried to shut down host Piers Morgan and leave for a dferent interview - as he said exasperated: For goodness sake Piers, let me finish!    Well, the person the Tories didnapost let finish was Mr Starmer. And Iaposm staggered frankly that youaposre not prepared to sit here - youaposve always struck me as an honourable, straight talker - how can you defend this  Itaposs fake news! Will, , flogged an old truck to pay for the bus and they also paid off £,worth of debt before moving onboard. During the renovation, -year-old Kristin fell pregnant and gave birth to daughter Roam in September last year. When she was just six months old, the couple moved onto the bus and began their new le. Will, who owns a creative video company, said: We have always enjoyed travel. Kristin spent her college years backpacking around dferent countries, and I was in the Boy Scouts. We both also travelled a lot for work.    We looked at a handful of dferent buses, but all had issues and werenapost very well kept. We could have done it with debt but wouldnapost have felt aposfreeapos and didnapost want to be dictated what we could do or where we go. Being debt free feels amazing. When we check our bank balance now, we feel a sense of peace and security. We have even been able to save money since moving into our tiny home and we are in the best place we have ever been in our entire lives. The family of four, including their pet dog Rush, travelled more than , miles from their previous home in Jacksonville, Florida, up the East Coast to Nova Scotia, Canada. Theyaposve stopped every few hours to change Roam, gave her time to crawl and feed her. Will called her a miracle baby.  The father added: Neither of us had planned on having any children, but we knew this was a miracle baby and was meant to be. After the initial shock set in, we were very excited to welcome our little one into the world. At night when we put her down to sleep, we have to be very quiet, so we donapost wake her. Other than those two things we donapost have too many dficulties. Roam has grown so much since she moved on board at six months old. title: mormon family massacre grieving dad
story: NewsGrieving dad reunited with baby girl after we and  family members massacredMum Christina Johnson saved her seven-month-old daughter Faith as she and eight other members of the LeBaron Mormon family were shot dead by drug cartel gunmen in MexicoShareCommentsByChris Kitching:,  NOV Updated:,  NOV NewsTyler Johnson is reunited with his baby daughter Faith, who escaped unharmed "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribe We will use your email address only for sending you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email A grieving father has been reunited with his baby girl after his we and eight other family members were slaughtered by a Mexican drug cartel.Mum Christina Johnson has been hailed a hero for saving her seven-month-old daughter Faith, who miraculously survived the massacre unharmed as bullets just missed her tiny body. Members of the LeBaron Mormon family feared Faith was killed along with her mum, but she was found alive strapped into her car seat on the floor of their SUV. More than  bullets were fired during the execution of three mothers and six children, who were travelling in a convoy of vehicles that may have been mistaken for a rival cartel. Faithaposs grandmother and aunts have shared a photo showing the moment the infant was reunited with her father, Tyler Johnson, who is pictured with a huge smile as he holds the girl in his arms on a sofa at home.    Family members have said Mrs Johnson, , put a blanket over Faith and threw her car seat on the floor to protect her from gunmen who were armed with assault rles. Cartel gunmen shot her in the chest at point-blank range when she got out of her car and raised her arms in the air to suggest she was surrendering and unarmed on a remote road in northern Mexico.Faithaposs grandmother, Connie LeBaron, wrote on Facebook: My son Tyler reunited with his baby Faith just now.God is so good for sparing her le.  She is a living angel and has brought hope to our family. Aunt Jolie Galaz, who also posted the photo of the father and daughter, wrote: My brother reunited with his baby! Thank you Jesus. God is so good and gave us hope in this sadness. We thought little Faith was dead for about  hours.  Until we got a message saying they found her in her car seat and her mama had put a blanket over her to protect her. My sweet angel. You are a miracle! I’m so happy your still here with us. Another aunt, Connie Johnson, wrote: My brother and his precious baby! I can’t wait to love on little Faith! She was in her car seat alone for hours. Bullets just missed her car seat!  After hours of people saying she had died we got the news that they found her alive. She’s such a miracle. Three mothers and six children - dual US-Mexico citizens - were killed in Mondayaposs slaughter, which has been blamed on a ruthless drug cartel. Mexican officials say it may have been a case of mistaken identity. The victims were members of the LeBaron family, a breakaway Mormon community whose ancestors settled in northern Mexico almost  years ago.  Distressing photos taken in the aftermath of the attack show a babyaposs blood-stained car seat, a babyaposs full milk bottle covered in blood and SUVs riddled with bullet holes. Mrs Johnson and Faith were travelling in one of the three SUVs that were ambushed near the Mormon community of La Mora, about  miles south of the US border, at about pm local time on Monday. Rhonita Miller, , and four of her children - Howard Miller, , Krystal Miller, , and twins Titus and Tiana Miller, both eight months - were all killed when their SUV was sprayed with bullets and destroyed by fire. Mum Dawna Langford, , and two of her children - Trevor Langford, , and Rogan Langford, two - died in a third vehicle.  Faith and Mrs Langfordaposs six other children survived the attack in the state of Sonora, which has been condemned by the Mexican and American presidents. Family said the Langford children who survived were Kylie, , who was shot in the foot Devin, , who was not injured and walked for hours to raise the alarm McKenzie, nine, whose arm was grazed by a bullet Cody, eight, who was shot in the face and the leg Jake, six, who escaped without injury Xander, four, who was shot in the back and eight-month-old Brixon, who was shot in the chest Devin hid his brothers and sisters with tree branches as he walked  miles home to get help. Family members said Mrs Miller was driving to Phoenix, Arizona, with her children to pick up her husband from the airport as he ed home from working in North Dakota.

title: abertay university leading project to promote childrens safety
story: Thousands of kids across the city throw themselves into gaming during their spare time, inadvertently working on their creativity, teamwork and social skills.But the virtual world in which they spend so much time is always evolving and throws up questions around safety and security for youngsters.Games such as Fortnite, Minecraft and Roblox connect hundreds of strangers and open up conversations between them.While most players have positive experiences, the question of how to keep kids safe from predators is one which still requires attention.In a bid to open up discussion around the subject and work towards possible solutions, Dr Darshana Jayemanne, a lecturer at Abertay University’s School of Design and Informatics, has created a new partnership to safeguard kids.Dr Jayemanne brought together gaming academics, students, developers and representatives from the NSPCC and the National Crime Agencyfor a conference at the university.He said: “Improving young people’s safety and privacy while playing digital games is something we have been researching at Abertay for several years and it’s fantastic to now be taking this forward with such a wide range of partners.“There are a number of complex issues around child safety in gaming and it is important that we work together.”Andy Burrows, NSPCC head of child safety online policy, said: “From our research, we know that children are at risk of being sexually groomed while playing games online. vw, px"  “The opportunity to work with other experts and those in the gaming industry on these issues is extremely positive.“To protect children from coming to harm on these s, it is vital that safety measures are built into the games when they are designed – something we hope can be achieved by working together.”Meanwhile, Karen Hutchison, senior officer with the NCA Child Exploitation and Online Protection Command, said: “We’re very proud to be part of this games sector partnership dedicated to combating child sex abuse and exploitation.”Max Bauer, head of customer service at Space Ape Games, said: “Safeguarding our communities is one of our top priorities. After all, they are what makes our games alive.“We, and other gaming studios, invest a lot of time and energy into this topic and it’s only fair to share our knowledge with the next generation of developers.”Abertay University is ranked number one in Europe for video games design degrees and leads the £. million Dundee-based InGAME partnership, which is part of the Arts and Humanities Research Council’s creative industries clusters programme and counts Beano Studios among its partners.InGAME director Sean Taylor of said: “We are delighted to be supporting this important project which has the potential to have a positive impact across the UK games industry.”Mike Stirling, head of Beano Studios, said: “We designed Beano and the games there to be totally safe for kids.“It’s an online destination that parents can trust.”

title: bookies on fintry road could be converted into new fish and chip shop
story: A former cop shop could be transformed from a bookies into a chippy.The old police station building on Fintry Road is currently a Betfred bookmaker.But now the city council has received a planning application to convert it into a fish and chip shop.Dundee architect Peter Inglis tabled the plans on behalf of Seafield Estates and confirmed that the business behind the move already has fish and chip shops around the city.He said: “The operator thinks the shop will employ five or six people working on ious shts.“I am not at liberty to say who the operator is, but it is based in and around Dundee with  employees.“The fit-out of the unit is relatively easy as there’s nothing structurally inside to change, but obviously they will have to install new kitchen equipment.“There is nothing dficult about the fit-out, although the shop won’t be open for Christmas.“It has still to go through planning to obtain permission.“And there is a council policy issue with the site being within  metres of a house.“However, the proposal includes the installation of a very sophisticated extraction system so that nearby homes are not affected.“Hopefully the council will see the s the applicant is going to for this.”Mr Inglis added: “Historically, we tried for a chip shop three years ago and the operator still wants to put a chip shop on that site.“But I don’t know anything about last year’s bid for a shop and I cannot give any details.“I wasn’t the architect back then.”A year ago, architect Mark Walker submitted an application on behalf of Seafield Estates for a non-food shop unit next to the Betfred outlet.At that time the council insisted on the proposed new shop being painted blue in keeping with the colours of Betfred to maintain the general look of the area.

title: dens boss mcpake wants players to put their stamp on dundee derby on friday
story: James McPake has urged his Dundee side to put their “stamp” on Friday night’s derby crunch at Dens Park from the first whistle.The Dark Blues host their city neighbours Dundee United aiming to cut their rivals’ six-point lead over them at the top of the Championship table.In the stands there will no doubt be a feeling of putting things right going into the second derby of the season after the first ended with a humiliating - thumping at Tannadice .James, however, insists that defeat will have no bearing on Friday’s contest for his team.He said: “We will look back on that game just as we wouldwe were playing Alloa or Morton.“We look back on the matches we have played against our opponents and analyse them – looking at strengths and weaknesses.“We can’t say that we should have had the goal that was chalked off because that’s irrelevant now. You can’t say: ‘Don’t worry about it boys, we can just turn up and we’ll get the right calls this time’.“You need to put your stamp on the match and hurt whoever you are playing. They will be thinking the same. The talk will not be about that game. It will be about this match and what it means to us as a club.”The Dens gaffer is in no doubt his side are a “stronger group” this time around.And he points to the quality that’s been added since in the shape of former West Brom, Norwich and Rangers midfielder Graham Dorrans.“I would say we are a stronger group,” James said.“We have added quality to the group. However, United will be stronger, too, because, although they didn’t make wholesale changes, they have been able to work with their players and they have been on a good run.“I think the benefits we have had on the training ground they will have had as well.“They may not have needed as much work but we felt we did need to put in the work on the training field in terms of how we go about things.“I think you can see that and, hopefully, you will see it on Friday night again.”He added: “I still don’t think we are completely there.“I don’t knowI will ever think that. In terms of training and that, then yes.“The international break came at a good time for us because we hadn’t yet had the chance to integrate Graham Dorrans into the squad.“We also had Jamie Ness coming back so it was a really good time to get a week’s training done.“Then we have had the games coming in thick and fast and you can see the benefit of that week.“The boys have been getting to know each other and what’s good and their strengths.“It is tough to just tell them that, you need to work on it day in, day out on the training field. I think even the top teams will tell you that.“Getting a settled squad after the window shut and being able to work with the boys – that has certainly helped us.”Meanwhile, the Dens boss is hopeful left-back Jordan Marshall will be fit to start on Friday after he limped off early in the - win over Morton last week.James said: “He is OK, I think. We left him out of training yesterday but he is gradually getting better. Hopefully, we caught it at the right time.“He did look a bit tired the other night, as did some others. We are asking Jordan and the others to press hard in the game but, hopefully, he will be all right.“The fans have taken to him and I can see why. He is very consistent and has a good end product as well which goes under-rated at times.“We will get him through this week and he will be fine.”A string of wins has seen Dundee rise to third in the table, behind Morton and league leaders United.

title: dundee uniteds lawrence shankland recalled to scotland squad for euro 2020 qualifiers
story: Dundee United hitman Lawrence Shankland has earned a recall to the Scotland squad for the upcoming Euro  qualiers.Shankland is in Steve Clarke’s -man squad for the campaign-closing games against Cyprus and Kazakhstan after scoring against San Marino and making his debut in Russia in the last round of matches.His inclusion in the Scots’ pool means he will miss United’s match against Queen of the South next weekend, with the national team in Cyprus on the same day before welcoming Kazakhstan to Hampden on the following Tuesday.

title: manhunt after teen knocked out at dundee newsagent
story: A newsagent was sealed off by police after a teenage boy was attacked and knocked unconscious.Emergency crews attended Umars Convenience Store on Pitkerro Road, in Mid Craigie, before the -year-old boy was taken to hospital on Friday afternoon.A police spokeswoman said officers are following a “positive” line of inquiry into the incident.It is understood two men and the teenager had been inside the store before the disturbance.Staff at the store declined to comment when approached about the incident.One customer said one of the men and the teenager became embroiled in a punch-up.He added: “I came to get my paper but the shop was shut and had been closed for some time.“These were all customers who are known to go into the shop on a regular basis.“I don’t know what triggered it but by all accounts the fight went on around the shop floor.”The Tele understands the teenager continued to be attacked as he lay unconscious on the ground.The customer added: “Only one of the men was involved as far as I’m aware but the other man pulled him away.“When I came past I clocked four police officers on the scene and two paramedics.“The teenager was on his feet when I saw him leaving.“By all accounts there had been a bit of blood spilled.“Police had closed the shop off as part of the investigation.“I feel sorry for the staff members who were inside the store.”The Police Scotland spokeswoman said: “Officers are following a positive line of inquiry after a -year-old boy was assaulted in a newsagent on Pitkerro Road, Dundee, on Friday.“The victim was taken to hospital for treatment for minor injuries.”

title: there are others like me who dont get the help they need after leaving carseview centre
story: To many looking from the outside Scott Smith had it all.The -year-old had a full-time job, a fiancée and three children before an accident at work changed his le in .Fast-forward four years – and the former road worker contemplates taking his own le every single day.A visibly distressed Scott today revealed he has dealt with a tumultuous few years that have transformed his le.The death of his sister Jennie Cameron was among a number of family losses in a short period of time.Her brave battle against cancer was documented in the Eveningbefore she died on the day she was due to be married in September .Scott was admitted to Carseview the following month after attempting to take his own le.Now the former St Saviour’s High pupil is urging for greater aftercare support for those struggling with mental health issues.He said: “Since I had an accident at work it has sort of spiralled from there.“From being a man who used to work to support his family to being like this is incredibly hard to take.“I was in Carseview on two separate occasions the month that I attempted to take my own le.“I still have suicidal thoughts daily.”His fiancée, Cheryl, had to become his carer as the family attempted to rebuild their le in Brechin.An unfortunate brush with the law had seen Scott appear in court earlier this year.The police found a haul of antique knives in his car on Fairbairn Street.Dundee Sherf Court heard Scott was encouraged to start collecting knives by his mental health nurses when he was staying at the Carseview Centre.Scott added: “I had just bought the antique knives that day.“It was a case of wrong place, wrong time, after dropping off a family friend.“That pending court case didn’t help with my on-going issues.”Scott had hoped with the support of the community mental health team he could get his le back on track in Angus.He admitted a lack of regular support had seen his progress “stall”.He added: “Whether its a lack of funding or overworked staff, I believe there are failings in the system.“I know of others who are in a similar position to me who feel they can’t get the help they need.“There are massive gaps in the system.”Scott said he wanted to tell his story so that people could be more aware that mental health issues “don’t just go away”.He added: “Despite leaving Carseview my mental health issues didn’t stop the day I left that door.“It is an ongoing struggle and you need those support measures in place.“I want to get the help to turn this around.“Although we have things like Mental Health Awareness Week I believe there is still a lack of understanding of the struggles people face.”A spokeswoman for Angus Health and Social Care Partnership said, “Multidisciplinary community mental health teams are available in every town in Angus.These teams include nurses, doctors, social workers, psychologists and allied health professionals.“Community Mental Health Teams also commission third sector services to deliver care in the home and the community seven-days-a-week.”

title: main aims for lethal strike duo alongside cosgrove
story: Buoyed by his first competitive Aberdeen goal, Curtis Main is confident he can forge a lethal strike partnership with Sam Cosgrove.Summer signing Main admits to frustration at both his lack of goaland game time since moving to Pittodrie.Chances have been limited and he was also hit by setbacks such as the dismissal last month against Hibs which he maintains was not a red card.Aberdeen opted not to appeal that sending-off and any momentum Main hoped to build was subsequently derailed by a two-game ban.However, the -year-old was given another opportunity when pitched in alongside prolic striker Cosgrove in a -- against Kilmarnock.It paid off as Main ended his competitive scoring drought and Cosgrove hit his th goal of the season.Main reckons they can become a dangerous duo in attack.He said: “I have no doubt Sam and myself can play together.“We showed against Kilmarnock there were spells in the game when we linked up really well.“I think everyone will be pleased with how we played attacking wise.“It is nice to play up there with another striker and you can build a relationship and work off each other’s game.“We are both imposing players but both link up well on the floor. It is not just one-dimensional.”His goalscoring performance against Kilmarnock was only the fourth start for the former Motherwell striker this season.Dons boss Derek McInnes has understandably opted to primarily use prolic striker Cosgrove to lead his attack.Cosgrove scored  times last season and is already closing in on that landmark again.Main said: “Absolutely, I have been frustrated. I just want to be on the park, playing minutes and scoring goals.“That is what I came here to do.“Behind the scenes I am working as hard as possible every day to put myself in a good position so that when the opportunities do come I am able to take them.“I have just had to keep my head down, work hard and wait for opportunities.“A few weeks ago I felt good in that gamebut unfortunately that didn’t go to plan.“I had to stay patient, stay ready and stay fit.“I am more than confident in my own ability. It is just about being on the park and showing everyone what I can do.”Main admits he has had discussions with manager McInnes about his lack of game time since signing on at Pittodrie.He said: “The manager is open and honest and I have had conversations with him through the season so far.“It is a competitive squad and it is about putting myself in a position to be in the squad and be in the team.”McInnes handed Main the opportunity to impress in the - draw with Hibs in his last appearance for the Dons on October .His strong performance was derailed when referee Don Robertson handed Main a straight red for a challenge on Stevie Mallan in the th minute.Main was shocked by the decision then and the red still rankles.He said: “It was disbelief. Absolute disbelief. I still maintain it was a good tackle. I think the boy made way too much of it.“I might have grazed his foot but there were a couple of incidents in the game where he was rolling round, which is totally unnecessary.“Unfortunately that is sometimes the way the game is played.“It was disheartening because I was in the team and had an opportunity. I felt I was playing well but I just had to forget it, put it to the back of my mind and wait for the next opportunity.“Thankfully that has come around very quickly and I managed to do something with it.”Main netted in the - pre-season friendly draw with Inverness Caley Thistle in July as part of the build-up to the Europa League campaign.He was delighted to finally score in a competitive match for Aberdeen and hopes it will be a catalyst for many more.He said: “ It was overdue and I am pleased that I have that goal.“Now I just have to move on and try to build on that.”

title: mcinnes hails dons for bouncing back
story: Aberdeen boss Derek McInnes today praised his under-pressure squad for bouncing back from their Celtic humiliation.The Reds were slaughtered by supporters and critics for the recent - loss where all Celtic’s goals came in the first half.McInnes demanded an immediate reaction and set a target of maximum points from the remaining three games before the international break.Aberdeen have delivered six with back-to-back wins against Hamilton and Kilmarnock.They travel to Ross County on Saturday before the Premiership goes into a week’s shutdown for the Euro  qualiers.McInnes said: “There was a bit of scrutiny on us after Celtic and I think the players have done extremely well to win both games with both clean sheets.“It is just a start for us and hopefully we can go on and get a third win in a row against Ross County next week. And go into the international break feeling a bit better about ourselves.”McInnes opted to partner strikers Sam Cosgrove and Curtis Main in a -- system against a Kilmarnock side struggling to field recognised centre-backs due to injury and suspension.It paid off with Main netting his first competitive goal for the Dons since his summer move.Cosgrove also scored to take his tally for the season to  goals.McInnes believes the score-line should have been more emphatic as Aberdeen were denied a penalty claim by referee Kevin Clancy.Cosgrove was brought down by a clumsy tackle from Stephen Hendrie in the box in the second half but the whistler waved play on.McInnes said: “We should have had a penalty with Cosgrove in the second half when he got wiped out in the bottom corner.“We also hit the post so it was good to get the third goal to add a bit of polish to the result.“Kilmarnock don’t normally lose too many goals so I am pleased with that scoreline against them.”The international break will give McInnes and his first-team squad the time to move into the new £ million training facility at Kingsford.Although the youth academy officially moved into Cormack Park yesterday, the first team squad have delayed it.Following the official opening by Sir Alex Ferguson on Thursday, they used the facilities for the first time the following day.McInnes said: “Cormack Park is a huge step forward for the club. It is brilliant facility for us all to enjoy.“We trained there on Friday with the team and it was the first chance the players had really got to see it.“We will train there again on Friday because we are not moving in full-time yet.“The academy kids and coaches started there on Monday and we will move in the following week.”Cormack Park is phase one of a £m plus development at Kingsford with phase two the delivery of a ,-capacity stadium.That was initially scheduled to be opened in summer  but that date is likely to be moved back a year until summer .McInnes said: “The players getting that first sense of Cormack Park and enjoying our own environment is fantastic for the professional side of the club.“However, it is great for the whole region. For the development of our players and coaches it is going to be a godsend.“It is what we should have had as we have been way behind other clubs in facilities.“Now we have a facility to be rightly proud of.”

title: north east road remains shut after river bursts its banks
story: Parts of the north-east were hit by flooding causing road closures across the region and a river to burst its banks.The Scottish Environment Protection Agencyissued a flood alert ahead of yesterday’s heavy downpour.The Met Office said two inches of rain fell in around  hours which is almost half of the average rainfall for November.The B Kintore to Hatton of Fintray road, near Kintore Golf Club, was closed in both directions due to water flooding the surface and the River Don burst its banks at Inverurie.Aberdeenshire Council was also forced to close the Glassel Road with motorists being asked to find alternative routes.mdash Aberdeenshire RoadsNovember , A spokesman for the police advised motorists to take care while driving on saturated roads.He said: “If your vehicle loses grip, or “aquaplanes” on surface water, take your foot off the accelerator to slow down. Do not brake or steer suddenly because you have no control of the steering or brakes.“If you have to drive through floods, drive slowly using first gear and try to keep the engine revving at a high rate.“Move forward continuously to avoid stalling the engine. If driving an automatic vehicle, engage and hold in a low gear. Check your mirror and test your brakes after driving through water to make sure they are still working properly.”A spokesman for the Met Office said it will be cold but dry for tonight’s bonfire celebrations across the region although there could be a risk of some showers.He said tomorrow should also be drier.
