title: school-pupils-tranent-come-together-climate-conversation
story: A Big Climate Conversation was held in St Martinrsquos Church Hall last Friday.School pupils were the main organisers of the event, marketed as: ldquoWhat the hell do the kids in Tranent know about climate change The community was welcomed to share their views on how Scotland can respond to the global climate emergency and feedback will be provided to the Scottish Government.The interactive conversation was led by children and featured games and music encouraging the people of Tranent to think about climate change as a human rights issue which must be addressed.The children in charge made sure the event was as carbon neutral as possible and even rented reusable plastic plates from Lower Impact Living, East Saltoun, to serve food on.At the end of the event, they had participants make pledges about what they were personally going to do to help tackle climate change.The event was organised by volunteers from Ross High School, Pencaitland Primary School, St Martinrsquos Eco Group, Farsquoside Womenrsquos Group and the Childrenrsquos Parliament and was sponsored by the Scottish Governmentrsquos The Big Climate Conversation Community Fund.Amy Gossner, , from Ross High School, was one of the youngsters key in organising the event and said: ldquoWe want everyone to be more aware of climate change.ldquoI think a lot of people donrsquot realise how much climate change is going to impact everyone in the future.ldquoItrsquos not just happening on TV, itrsquos happening everywhere in the world and itrsquos everyonersquos responsibility.ldquoOur aim is to find out what people in the community, especially children, think is the way forward and what they think other people can do to help prevent climate change.Claire MacGillivray, a Trustee of the Childrenrsquos Parliament, said: ldquoOn the back of this event, we will be sending a report to the Scottish Government but I think itrsquos really about starting the conversation.We have a reason to make the world a better place: for our children. They are taking the lead by showing adults that they want things to change.Paul Reynolds, headteacher at Ross High School, said: ldquoI am delighted that our pupils are proactively seeking to raise awareness of these issues and look at ways to make positive changes.ldquoWe also have a group looking at ways to highlight this important issue in school so this is clearly an issue which means a lot to our pupils.The Big Climate Conversation Community Fund was launched in August to assist community organisations to host workshops and engage in the climate change debate. It is managed by Impact Funding on behalf of the Scottish Government.Sixty-two groups have been approved to receive funding so far which project to engage more than , members of the public in the climate conversation.

title: liberal-democrats-formally-adopt-general-election-candidate-east-lothian
story: The Lib Dems had been the first party to select a General Election candidate in the county, announcing back in March that the partys East Lothian convenor Robert ORiordan would be their prospective candidate in the anticipation of an election being held in the near future.Now that a General Election has been formally announced for December , the Lib Dems formally adopted Mr ORiordan as their candidate for East Lothian at a meeting in Haddington.Mr OrsquoRiordan has lived in Gullane since . He is married with three grown-up children and retired from a -year career in investment in Edinburgh four years ago.Mr ORiordan said: ldquoWe have been preparing for this election for some time and are determined to put up a good fight."Our message is strong ndash Lib Dems want the UK to stay in Europe and we also want Scotland to stay in the UK. This resonates with voters throughout East Lothian."Voters are fed up with isive politics and want governments at Westminster and Holyrood to get back to their proper job ndash tackling urgent and pressing environmental, social and economic challenges. Parties need to work with each other and not against each other to achieve this."Mending our broken politics, including constitutional reform and the introduction of proportional representation at Westminster, are top of my shopping list.In next months poll, Mr ORiordan is up against sitting MP Martin Whitfield , former Justice Secretary Kenny MacAskilland Haddington and Lammermuir ward councillor Craig Hoy .Nominations for the election close at pm next Thursday .In the last election in , Mr Whitfield pulled in , votes to beat the SNPs George Kerevan , who finished narrowly ahead of Sheila Low of the Conservatives . The Liberal Democrats were fourth with , votes, while independent Mike Allan received  votes.

story: Tchai-OvnaHidden down a wee cobbled lane in the heart of Glasgowrsquos West End, on entering Tchai-Ovna you would be forgiven for thinking you are stepping into a Himalayan tea room or a Turkish bazar.Tchai-Ovna was founded in  by a group of Glasgow University students tired of the prevalent alcohol culture. When they first discovered the location, an old th C stables, it was badly in need of some t.l.c. but its magical, Bohemian, offbeat atmosphere was perfect. Too young to get business funding, with help from friends and the community they invested their student loans and refurbished the premises, keeping as many original features as possible: cobbled floors, horsersquos tethers etc. The vegetarian speciality tea house they created was only supposed to last a year, but almost twenty years on it is now a firmly established Glasgow institution."@context": "https:schema.org","@type": "VideoObject","name": "Tchai-Ovna","description": "Tchai-Ovna","thumbnailUrl": "https:cdn.jwplayer v media dSMDgrx poster.jpg width","uploadDate": "--T::+:","duration": "PDTHMS","contentUrl": "https:cdn.jwplayer manests dSMDgrx.mu","embedUrl": "https:www.heraldscotland video  ","publisher": "@type": "Organization","name": "HeraldScotland","logo": "@type": "ImageObject","url": "https:www.heraldscotland sitelogo ","width": ,"height": Today the menu represents a broad swathe of cultures including Mexican, Arabic and Indian. It is produced by award winning vegetarian specialists the chipotle chilli won an award for one of the best chillis in the West End, and it is completely vegan. The vegan curry, produced by Balbirs Restaurants celebrated Punjabi chefs is hearty, tasty and authentic. Whilst you are enjoying your meal you can partake in one of around  speciality teas, all Tchai-Ovna own brand, and many of them blended in house and to order. They also retail many of the teas in the shop and online as well as wholesale across Scotland.Many know Tchai-Ovna as a much loved community hub, where people of all ages and backgrounds meet to socialise, play board games and listen to local, and international, live music acts and performances. It is welcoming, informal and unpretentious. Perhaps it is for this reason that even well-known celebs have become patrons. Belle and Sebastienrsquos album art for Dear Catastrophe Waitress was shot here, members of Franz Ferdinand stop by when they are not on tour, and Scarlett Johansson likes it so much she has been twice.Whatever your reason, be sure to stop by for a cuppa when you are in Glasgow.www.tchaiovna Otago LaneGlasgowG PBOpen am-pm every day----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Hanoi Bike ShopVietnamese food was vegan friendly before vegans were vegan. The streets of Hanoi are filled with vegetables and fresh produce that many of us here in Scotland have never heard of, let alone tasted. Plant-based food is everywhere in Vietnam and at the Hanoi Bike Shop they continue this tradition without ever sacricing taste or flavour.The little restaurant is situation just off Byres Road in the West End. The twinkly lights, Vietnamese flags and vintage bikes will draw you down the lane but once you get through the door donrsquot be put by the smell, they swear itrsquos not lsquowet dogrsquo or lsquohamster cagesrsquo as some TripAdvisor reviews would have you think. Fish sauce is a staple in Vietnamese cuisine and does leave a lasting impression on the senses. Although they use Tamariin all of their vegan dishes the fresh pho broths are always on the boil and help to give Hanoi its distinctive odour.Hanoi Bike Shop chefs have created a vegan menu influenced by seasonal availability of local produce as well as the salty, sweet, sour and spicy balance of Vietnamese cuisine.The star of course, is their organic handmade tofu, which is carefully, simmered, strained and pressed daily in house.Hanoirsquos vegan menu consists of over twenty freshly prepared dishes ranging from Kimchi Spring Rolls and Daikon and Soya Bean Cakes to Chilli Glazed Sesame Rice Cakes and Curried Banana.They implore all customers to adopt their dining motto lsquosharing is caringrsquo and go for the lsquoFeed Mersquo option. Then you just sit back, relax and let the banquet begin.www.hanoibikeshopInstagram www.instagram hanoibikeshop Facebook www.facebook TheHanoiBikeShop booking.resdiary widget Standard HanoiBikeShop  ----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------OM Sweet OMOM Sweet OM is a vibrant haven, tucked behind Central Station in Oswald St, in the centre of Glasgow, committed to the art of sustainable happiness and conscious living. The charity is set up to promote well-being which will empower you to experience a higher taste in le thus satisfying your physical, emotional and spiritual needs.Inspired by the ancient Bhakti tradition of Vedic culture they integrate and unite the ious yoga systems to form a lestyle to benefit yourself, those around you, the planet and all of its ied inhabitants.OM Sweet OM practice Ahimsa, the principle of non-violence, in their vegan dishes and lestyle to increase compassion for all living beings and reduce harm to our environment. A plant-based diet is crucial for their inidual wellbeing and that of the planet itself.Most of their events feature vegan meals and all of the meals served in OM Sweet OM are lovingly prepared by the cooks at Krishna Eco Farm www.facebook krishnaecofarm  to a very high standard, often using produce fresh from the gardens. The most popularevent is the Vegan All You Can Eat Feast where everyone is personally served a delicious thali-style meal until fully satisfied...and then dessert. They have a thriving programme providing free vegan food on the streets of Glasgow via the project Food for Scotland www.facebook foodscotland. This is aimed at homeless people and also promote plant-based diets."@context": "https:schema.org","@type": "VideoObject","name": "OM Sweet OM","description": "OM Sweet OM","thumbnailUrl": "https:cdn.jwplayer v media PfqkSp poster.jpg width","uploadDate": "--T::+:","duration": "PDTHMS","contentUrl": "https:cdn.jwplayer manests PfqkSp.mu","embedUrl": "https:www.heraldscotland video  ","publisher": "@type": "Organization","name": "HeraldScotland","logo": "@type": "ImageObject","url": "https:www.heraldscotland sitelogo ","width": ,"height": Just as the body needs nourishment by vegan superfood, they also offer yoga classes to maintain a good flow of healthy energy. They have classes to suit all levels of practitioners and even entry level by donation to encourage newcomers to try. Award-winning yoga teacher, Daniel Gronan, has several lively classes featuring vinyasa yoga and mantra movement.For those wanting to e deeper into philosophy, there are classes available to discover and discuss timeless yoga wisdom of India. The western giants of modern philosophy all take their roots from the Sanskrit teachings. Many psychologists and neurologists are realising the benefits of mantra sound vibrations on our well-being.In conjunction with Krishna Eco Farm, retreats are available to immerse oneself in yoga, mindfulness and mantra meditation in the beautul countryside of Lesmahagow, with wonderful vegan meals.OM Sweet OM, Food for Scotland and Krishna Eco Farm are all projects of ISKCON Scotland, charity number SC.www.omsweetomwww.facebook omsweetomglasgowwww.instagram omsweetom.glasgow----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Kalpna Indian Vegan and Vegetarian RestaurantOpen since , Kalpna Indian Vegan and Vegetarian Restaurant stands as one of Edinburghrsquos most established Institution. During this time, it has won several awards for excellence in Indian and vegan and vegetarian categories.In their dishes they use only the freshest ingredients, which, wherever possible has been sourced locally.They remain a family run restaurant serving high quality Indian vegan and vegetarian food to the people of Scotland for over a quarter of a century and many of their customers have been visiting the restaurant since their childhood. The restaurant is often referred to as an institution rather than a restaurant.The owner is passionate about a vegetarian and vegan lestyle and the family is dedicated to introducing people to the pleasures of Indian vegetarian food. The chefs at Kalpna draw on their vast experience in Punjabi, Gujrati and South Indian delicacies.www.kalpnarestaurant--------------------------PicnicPicnic was opened in late  by Michelle Morrow, as a healthy and ethical alternative to the many other food outlets in the Merchant City area. With a  per cent cruelty free menu - yet appealing to vegans and nonvegans alike - Picnic quickly established itself as an extremely popular place for a fantastic, healthy breakfast, a delicious lunch or luscious slice of cake and a cup of co#ee.Picnic serves a wide range of freshly prepared, healthy vegan food, including delectable homemade wa#es, salads, wraps, soup, curry, sandwiches, juices and some of the best smoothies in Glasgow.At weekends and on public holidays, Picnic serve a phenomenal full cooked breakfast, which, although healthy, is every bit as satisfying as the traditional full Scottish. Everybody is welcome and you can even bring your dog along with you.Naturally, Picnic has been a big hit with Glasgowrsquos rising number of vegans. However, yoursquoll also #nd many non-vegan regulars frequenting the cafe, all enjoying the terri#c food and the friendly vibe. Picnic is very highly rated across all major online review s. Picnic is also ranked in the top  globally by the same website.Going into its rd year - as Glasgow City Centrersquos #rst  per cent vegan cafe - Picnic continues to set the standard for healthy and ethical food.Be sure to pay Picnic a visit, next time you are in the Merchant City area.www.picnicwww.instagram picnic.glasgow www.facebook picnic.glasgow

title: no-nonsense-new-speaker-not-afraid-ruffle-snp-feathers
story: The -year-old Labour politician, who was knighted in  for parliamentary and political services, also clashed with former Scottish First Minister Alex Salmond during a Brexit debate in February .Mr Salmond accused the Deputy Speaker of cutting off SNP MP Joanna Cherry while she was speaking and the row escalated as Mr Hoyle shouted that Mr Salmond ldquoshould know better and ordered him to ldquosit down. Tempers were rising after seven hours of debate as the Brexit Bill that would trigger Article  reached committee stage in the Commons.:Sir Lindsay Hoyle elected new speaker of the House of CommonsThe row occurred after the Mr Salmond raised a point of order saying: "It is quite clear that the honourable member had not resumed her seat, Sir. Being in the chair accords you many privileges but you cannot reinterpret the wishes of an honourable member who is on her feet."Mr Hoyle responded: "As the chair I have the right to make decisions on this House. What I would say is quite rightly when I wanted to bring her in [Joanna Cherry MP], which I did ... I certainly dont expect advantages to be taken of the chair on the agreements that I make."Referring to the Brexit Bill, he said: "It is a very serious matter, it is so serious that I want to hear what the minister has to say."Mr Hoyle has been widely complimented for his approach to handling Budget debates, which has been part of his job as chairman of Ways and Means.:Sir Lindsay Hoyle elected new speaker of the House of CommonsHe taught his pet parrot Boris to shout ldquoorder order! and named his tortoise Maggie, after the late Tory Prime Minister because she had a hard shell and was "not for turning".The Lancashire-born businessman was one of just three Labour MPs who did not declare their voting intention in the  EU referendum. His Lancashire district backed Brexit by % to %.He vowed to "tame the bear pit" of a "toxic Parliament"elected to the role of Speaker, sayinghe would crack down on aggressive language.He went to private Lords College in Bolton and ran his own screen-printing firm before becoming an MP in .The seasonedpolitician was elected as Deputy Speaker of the House in a secret ballot on June .He was in the Speakerrsquos chair at the time of the Westminster Terror Attack of  March  - and the subsequent lockdown of the Houses of Parliament.After winning the final round of voting on Monday against Chris Bryant, Sir Lindsay was dragged to the chair by MPs, where he pledged to be a "neutral" Speaker.He also paid tribute to his daughter, Natalie, who died in , saying she would "always be missed".

title: neil-mackay-question-time-comes-scotland-week---must-stop-destruction-trust
story: During the last edition of the political  show the broadcaster allowed lies and disinformation to go out over the airwaves uncorrected, infecting public discourse.An audience member told the  that the Vote Leave campaign had broken electoral law, and said Dominic Cummings, the Prime Ministerrsquos special adviser, had refused to come before parliament.Presenter Fiona Bruce told the young woman: ldquoIrsquom not entirely sure yoursquore right about that. Bruce also appeared to confuse Vote Leave with the Leave.EU campaign.The young woman defended her position, but was told by Bruce ldquono criminal charges were brought.The right-wing journalist Isabel Oakeshott, who was a list, then jumped in to say: ldquoThe vast majority of allegations about both Leave campaigns were found to be completely untrue. This was propaganda.The audience member was correct, however ndash Vote Leave broke the law. Yet, any viewer would have left the programme believing the opposite.This is a critical failure by the BBC. The national broadcaster is meant to provide unbiased, accurate reporting. It did the opposite on Question Time.This General Election is one that will be fought on lies, deceit and manipulation. Thatrsquos why facts, truth and trust are the most vital issues for the electorate.Herersquos a reminder of what the BBC should have told viewers. Vote Leave was fined pound, for breaking electoral law over spending limits. In March this year, it dropped its appeal against the fine. Vote Leave was fronted by Boris Johnson. Cummings was campaign director.The Electoral Commission said: ldquoSerious offences such as these undermine public confidence in our system and it is vital, therefore, that they are properly investigated and sanctioned.A day after Question Time aired, it emerged evidence relating to overspending, which could lead to criminal charges against Vote Leave, had been passed by police to the Crown Prosecution Service.The House of Commonrsquos Privileges Committee said Cummings had committed a contempt of Parliament by not appearing to give evidence when ordered as part of an inquiry into fake news.The fact that Question Time acted as a distributor for lies on an issue which is right at the very heart of Brexit and the forthcoming General Election makes the broadcasterrsquos failings ever more egregious.I donrsquot see bias at every turn with the BBC. Irsquove mostly great respect for the broadcaster in terms of its journalism and also its cultural output. When I see it attacked by both right and left, Leave and Remain, unionists and Yes voters, Irsquom pretty confident itrsquos doing its job and holding all sides of the political spectrum to account. Demonstrations against the BBC and hate campaigns against reporters run contrary to every democratic bone in my body. I see them as the first steps on the path to authoritarianism and populism.However, the BBC as a whole suffers from a fatal weakness: its automatic default position is to defend the status quo. When authority speaks, it accepts and parrots, it doesnrsquot question and interrogate. Radical voices are subjected to withering scrutiny, reactionary voices are treated with respect and dignity. This skews debate and immediately sets up imbalance.We saw the same problem here in Scotland during the independence referendum. The knee-jerk position was to subject the Yes campaign to forensic investigation, while broadly accepting most of what the No campaign said on face value. Both sides should have been put under the same pressure.There are also flaws built in to Question Time, which are now becoming damaging to democracy. The show isnrsquot about debate and getting to the facts, itrsquos TV clickbait. Itrsquos about screaming matches and outrage. Itrsquos a shock-jock show dressed up in the boring clothes of a politician.:Election : Jeremy Corbyn accuses Boris Johnson over NHSHere in Scotland, wersquore used to the games Question Time plays. Eyebrows were raised when a former UKIP member called Billy Mitchell appeared on the show for the fourth time in Scotland. Mitchell claimed he was invited by the showrsquos producer.The damage done to the BBCrsquos reputation by last weekrsquos show was immediate and deep. Shahmir Sanni, the whistleblower who exposed Vote Leave spending, said: ldquoOh my f**king God. Theyrsquore not even trying to hide it anymore! This audience member recalls Vote Leave breaking electoral law and Fiona Bruce literally lies saying lsquothey were cleared of those accusationsrsquo.Wersquoll be in serious trouble during this electionthe BBC shatters trust in itself. The public needs the BBC more than ever as an arbiter of whatrsquos true and whatrsquos lies in this era of mass manipulation and propaganda.Johnsonrsquos government is currently sitting on a report into Russian interference in British democracy. Dominic Grieve, the former Tory attorney-general, has called for its publication before the election.:Glasgow set to host BBC Question Time in run up to general electionThe Labour Party has began to question Dominic Cummings links to Russia. Emily Thornberry, shadow foreign secretary, wrote to the government asking about his connections to Russia and the level of security vetting to which hersquos been subjected in Downing Street.Amid all this, wersquove the truly grave threat Facebook poses to democracy. The social media giant will allow British politicians to run  ads on the site. To make the matter even more disgusting, the policy is being championed by Facebook executive Nick Clegg, the former LibDem deputy Prime Minister, who once spoke out about ldquothe colossal scale of the lies spread by the Leave campaign.Johnson and his new Tory radicals are also shameless in their deceit. Outgoing European Commission President, Jean-Claude Junker, said yesterday of the EU referendum: ldquoSo many lies were told, including by current prime minister, Boris Johnson, that there needed to be a voice to counter them.Chief among the voices countering lies should be the BBC. It shouldnrsquot be amplying hoods. Perhaps, one starting solution would be to change the format of Question Time by adding in a fact-checker service. While the  debate, a team of journalists could sit behind them double-checkingwhat they are saying is true. If they lie, fact-checkers should interrupt the show and tell viewers the truth. That would be a real service to democracy, and to the public, when we need it most.Neil Mackay is Scotlandrsquos Columnist of the Year

Irsquom not surethe Brexit Party should look to Scotland as any great prospect in this election.ldquoI think the most recent analysis is something like -% of SNP voters would now support Brexit, there is not great support in Scotland for Brexit.She was also askedshe would do a deal with Jeremy Corbyn with the SNP leader stating that she would consider a case-by-case deal but that it would be a lsquohard bargainrsquo that would protect Scotland.Parliamentwill today be dissolved, marking the official start of the General Election campaign, with the UK going to the polls on December .

title: jacob-rees-mogg-apologises-grenfell-common-sense-comments
story: His apology came after an LBC appearance on Monday, during which the Commons leader had discussed London Fire Brigadersquoslsquostay-putrsquo policy and said: ldquoIf you just ignore what yoursquore told and leave you are so much safer.ldquoI thinkeither of us were in a fire, whatever the fire brigade said, we would leave the burning building.ldquoIt just seems the common sense thing to do, and it is such a tragedy that that didnrsquot happen."@context": "https:schema.org","@type": "VideoObject","name": "Jacob Rees-Mogg apologises for Grenfell common sense comment","description": "Jacob Rees-Mogg apologises for Grenfell common sense comment","thumbnailUrl": "https:cdn.jwplayer v media fKXzcJ poster.jpg width","uploadDate": "--T::+:","duration": "PDTHMS","contentUrl": "https:cdn.jwplayer manests fKXzcJ.mu","embedUrl": "https:www.heraldscotland video  ","publisher": "@type": "Organization","name": "HeraldScotland","logo": "@type": "ImageObject","url": "https:www.heraldscotland sitelogo ","width": ,"height": But after calls to apologise, Mr Rees-Mogg said on Tuesday: ldquoWhat I meant to say is that I would have also listened to the fire brigadersquos advice to stay and wait at the time.ldquoHowever, with what we know now and with hindsight I wouldnrsquot and I donrsquot think anyone  would.ldquoI would hate to upset the people of GrenfellI was unclear in my comments.The originalcomments were called ldquocrass and ldquoinsensitive by Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn, and Grenfell United said his words were ldquoextremely painful and insulting to bereaved families.The Leader of the House of Commons suggesting that the  people who lost their lives at Grenfell lacked common sense is beyond disrespectful. It is extremely painful and insulting to bereaved families.mdash Grenfell UnitedNovember , On Tuesday, thehead of the London Fire Brigadesaid that ldquoknowing what we know now, the service would respond dferently to a Grenfell-like fire.LFB Commissioner, Dany Cotton, was answering questions at the London Assembly about the inquiry report into the  blaze that killed  people.She told the fire, resilience and emergency planning committee: ldquoClearly, knowing what we know now about Grenfell Tower and similar buildings with ACM cladding, our response would be very dferent.When asked how the service had changed its approaches, she added: ldquoNot only have we increased our attendancewe receive a call to a high rise fire, we increase the number of fire engines we send.What possesses someone to react to an entirely avoidable tragedy like Grenfell by saying the victims lacked common sense  People were terried, many died trying to escape. Jacob Rees Mogg must apologise for these crass and insensitive comments immediately.https:t.co QczWiyxkRmdash Jeremy CorbynNovember , ldquoIf there are multiple calls to the same building and the callers state the outside of the building is on fire we send an initial attendance of ten fire engines, plus officers, plus specialist appliances.Ms Cotton also expressed concern for the number of buildings covered in similar material to the Kensington tower.She told the committee: ldquoWe know that there are still several hundred buildings in London that are covered in ACM cladding [hellip] our concern is that action is not being taken quickly enough to remove that cladding which is a high risk.

title: brexit-could-mean-border-checks-england-scotland-wales
story: Issues such as chlorinated chicken and genetically-modiedcrops in post-Brexit trade negotiations could create wider dferences between the nationsrsquo food safety standards and require border checks between countries, University of Sussex academics have said.With the Scottish and Welsh Governments pledging to remain aligned to EU standards after Brexit, trade deals made by the UK Government ldquocould complicate and undermine trade in agricultural and food products, the report states.:Neil Mackay: Question Time comes to Scotland this week ndash it must stop the destruction of trust"@context": "https:schema.org","@type": "VideoObject","name": "Brexit:  days until Britain is scheduled to leave the EU","description": "Brexit:  days until Britain is scheduled to leave the EU","thumbnailUrl": "https:cdn.jwplayer v media KdZxfJE poster.jpg width","uploadDate": "--T::+:","duration": "PDTHMS","contentUrl": "https:cdn.jwplayer manests KdZxfJE.mu","embedUrl": "https:www.heraldscotland video  ","publisher": "@type": "Organization","name": "HeraldScotland","logo": "@type": "ImageObject","url": "https:www.heraldscotland sitelogo ","width": ,"height": Our new briefing paper is finally out! We look at Brexit food safety legislation on GMOs, pesticides, food additives and microbiological food safetyand its potential trade impacts: https:t.co RerBdHmdash Emily LydgateNovember , The university study, carried out for the UK Trade Policy Observatory, said dferent approaches to food standards would likely have a ldquosignicant and detrimental impact on the ability to strike trade deals and ldquoposes an increased risk of fragmentation within the UK.Proposed Brexit food safety rules would give UK ministers powers to make policy changes to food safety laws without primary legislation ndash avoiding the scrutiny of Parliament through the use of Statutory Instruments .:Mark Smith: The  Scottish seats that matter ndash and the critical group of voters that will decide who wins themSuch changes have the potential to ldquovastly increase devolution of food safety regulation, according to the report, creating the prospect of trade barriers between England and Scotland or Wales.Dr Emily Lydgate, a senior environmental law lecturer at the University of Sussex and one of the authors of the study, said: ldquoFood safety SIs are a potential flash-point for Scotland ndash which wants to maintain alignment with the EU ndash and Westminster, which promises to pursue a US trade deal that will alter UK food safety legislation.ldquoNegotiating a US trade deal that Scotland opposes is certainly not viable and could even fuel a push for Scottish independence.ldquoIf one or more devolved administrations refuses to realign its food safety regulations from those of the EU to comply with US standards after a US-UK free trade agreement, it will complicate the flows of agricultural and food products within the UK.ldquoThis raises the question of how the UK can avoid introducing internal UK regulatory controls and border checks to ensure that products comply with ergent jurisdictional requirements.The report also suggests EU safeguards on food standards will be weakened as soon as the UK leaves, with the Government planning to scrap the requirement for independent scientic assessments on the safety of pesticides and allowing minister to lower thresholds for labelling when genetically-modied crops are used.Professor Erik Millstone, emeritus professor in the Science Policy Research Unit at the University of Sussex, said: ldquoOur analysis suggests Brexit SIs will allow ministers to exercise considerable powers of discretion when authorising ingredients in pesticide products, amending GMO authorisations and thresholds for labelling, authorising food additives and approving substances for animal carcass washes.ldquoMinisters may issue guidance impacting substantive policy content or make new rules governing food safety by secondary legislation, without proper parliamentary scrutiny and using powers that exceed those vested by the EU in the European Commission.ldquoThose considerable powers could be a way to overcoming parliamentary resistance and public opposition to aspects of a UK-US trade deal.Recommending that devolved nations have ldquostrong oversight over UK external trade negotiations, the study also calls for primary legislation to be required where there could be major policy changes on food safety.

title: worlds-oldest-working-post-office-dumfries-galloway-goes-sale
story: Sanquhar Post Office in Dumfries and Galloway opened in , eight years before the second oldest one in Stockholm, Sweden.It comes with a three-bedroom cottage, a courtyard and some outbuildings that were originally the home of the Mail Coaches Horses, according to the estate agent listing.Current owners Nazra Alam, , and her husband Dr Manzoor Alam, , took over the business in  but have now put it on the market as they are retiring.:Discover ten hidden gems in Dumfries and GallowayThey are hopeful someone will buy the property and save the post office from closing after more than  years in operation.Mrs Alam said: ldquoI hope someone will come along and buy it and keep it going because this is Scotlandrsquos heritage and more particularly Sanquharrsquos.ldquoThe post office has been in operation since  so it would be a shame to have to shut it down.ldquoItrsquos part of the community, we offer full postal services, banking and wersquove got stationery and a gt section.The mother-of-two added: ldquoIrsquove enjoyed every moment of running it.ldquoThe last five years has been a remarkable journey and Irsquove enjoyed it, itrsquos a nice area and nice people and we have visitors from all over the world.:Post Office in crisis and on the brink of collapseThe post office is recognised by Guinness World Records as theoldest one in operation.The second oldest, located in Stockholm, opened in  while the third, in Santiago, Chile, opened in .

title: scientist-tells-nightmare-unfair-sacking-biotech-firm-neogen
story: Jenner MacAulay was dismissed from food safety technology firm Neogen Europebecause of a ldquopersonality clash with her manager - despite the firmrsquos HR department warning there wasnrsquot ldquoanything to take her to disciplinary on.She was sacked for conduct issues but received no verbal or written warnings from the Ayrshire firm and performed well throughout her seven years there, gaining several positive appraisals and promotion.The -year-old has now won her case for unfair dismissal at an employment tribunal after Neogen conceded that it had treated her unfairly.Read more:Barrhead Travel faces unfair dismissal claim from founder and former owner Bill MunroEmployment judge Rory McPherson said the company had acted ldquounreasonably and awarded the scientist almost pound,.Ms MacAulay told The Herald: ldquoBeing unfairly dismissed and the events leading up to it have taken their toll on me. It took at least a month before I felt like I could try and pick myself up and apply for other jobs.ldquoEven then, I am inevitably asked why I left Neogen Europe and itrsquos awkward having to try and explain what happened.ldquoIf it wasnrsquot for my savings and support from family, I could have been in serious financial dficulty.ldquoThe whole thing has been an unbelievable nightmare.Ms MacAulay began working at Neogen as a research technician in , before being promoted to research scientist four years later.During that time she was described as a ldquokey member of the firmrsquos Research and Development team, with her then manager describing her as ldquovery adaptable, easy to manage, and very focused.However, in April  Dr Jay Wallace took over as the new manager of the team and things began to change.At no time did she raise any concerns directly with Ms MacAulay, but she spoke to HR about the scientistrsquos interactions and relationships with her and other members of staff.Read more:BBC lsquois facing wave of pay claim tribunalsrsquo as Ahmed case beginsAn email from HR to the then managing director Stephen Holmes in May  stated: ldquoFrom what Dr Wallace has told me there really isnrsquot anything to take her to disciplinary on, aside from perhaps failure to follow management instructions but even then it is thin and the furthest we could probably take it is a written warning which would probably lead to more animosity.It added: ldquoDr Wallace seems to be getting to the point where she canrsquot work with her anymore. The only practical way I can think to get rid of[Ms MacAulay] would be by way of a compromise agreement.The following month Ms MacAuley was told that she was being investigated by Dr Wallace. She then went on to face a disciplinary hearing concerning accusations of ldquoinsubordination and ldquoacting in a manner that undermines or demotivates other members of the team and or management.She was dismissed at the conclusion of the hearing by Steve Chambers, who is now managing director of the firm.Ms MacAulay said: ldquoSteve said that the decision had been made to terminate my employment. He said he wasnrsquot going to tell me why I was being dismissed and that it would be explained to me in a letter.ldquoAnd that was it. My seven year career in RD at Neogen Europe was over, and they wouldnrsquot even tell me why.Her dismissal letter stated that there ldquowas evidence of a clear breakdown in working relationships, an evident personality clash and inability to work effectively and co-operatively.She tried to appeal but bosses refused to allow it.Ms MacAulay asked the tribunal to order the firm to reinstate her, or offer her an alternative position, but judge McPherson refused.However, her award was increased by  per cent as a result of the firmrsquos failure to follow the ACAS code of practice.Ms MacAulay added:I am very pleased to have been awarded the maximum amount of compensation possible, and the maximum uplt of  per cent.ldquoI think that reflects the terrible series of serious failings on Neogen Europersquos part.Read more:Glasgow appeal against employment rights for foster carers set to be heardA spokesman for Neogen said: ldquoThis case was regrettable because it concerned a breakdown in relationships at work, a dficulty for Neogen, that Neogen had to take steps to address.ldquoMs MacAulay sought to get her job back, but this was resisted by Neogen on account of the circumstances surrounding Ms MacAulayrsquos departure.ldquoNeogen was pleased that the tribunal agreed that Ms MacAulay should not be ed to work in Neogen, accepting that the underlying reason for her departure was a genuine and rational view that there had been an irretrievable breakdown in relationships at work.

title: bake-offs-flora-shedden-my-generation-delusional-approach-food
story: If the Think Global, Eat Local mantra is being appropriated by mindful Millennials , then Flora Shedden is arguably a standard-bearer of the generations she spans. Originally coined some years ago by older campaigners wishing for a more sustainable, secure and resilient system of food production and distribution, the -year-old Scot is taking up the baton ndash albeit it on a tiny Perthshire footprint.Four years ago, at the age of , the Dunkeld-born student became the youngest-ever finalist in the long-running reality baking show The Great British Bake-Off [GBBO]. Watched by  million viewers worldwide, she was the runner-up in the  finale and instantly became a media darling. Evidently thrilled and reassured in equal measure to have such a young woman embrace ndash in her reassuring mid-Scots accent ndash the ancient culinary art of baking using centuries-old techniques, print and broadcast commissioning editors flocked to her oven door. Her first cookbook was published, and her online presence rose faster than the lightest souffle. Here was a new domestic goddess in whose delicate hands baking was safe. The world, it seemed, was her ice-cream oyster.Then she turned the tables. Eschewing the bright lights, she has settled instead for her own tiny craft bakery in a th century village in rural Perthshire where she quietly and happily puts in a -hour day. Itrsquos from this modest ndashinfinitely pretty ndash base that she hopes to influence our relationship with food for the better.Not that shersquos about to disappear completely: with its white-painted -year-old stone walls, original black range, front door draped with garlands of dried flowers, the setting for her glass-fronted display of fresh craft bakery items, Aran, is the last word in Instagrammability. Named after the Gaelic for bread, it is also the title of her second cookbook.ldquoYeah, it was a bit of a ballsy move, she agrees of her snap decision to buy the bakery in . ldquoItrsquos been wonderful. I call it my flour oasis. Wersquore perched on little white-painted stepping stools in a corner of the busy shop floor, trying not to get in the way of the constant stream of customers ndash a combination of locals and tourists ndash looking for her trademark homemade croissants, cakes, pastries and sourdough breads which have sustainability hard-baked into every bite.Shedden put her studies on hold ndash she was doing a history of art degree at St Andrews ndash to set up Aran with her friend Angus and her boyfriend of just five months at the time, James Irvine, who now manages the Birnam Arts Centre. The pair live together in the flat above the shop. A crowdfunding campaign raised pound, for refurbishment and grants from the SSE windfarm community fund, combined with a bank loan and proceeds from her first book Gatherings, made her long-held dream possible.ldquoIrsquod immediately become jealous when Angus told me he had a lsquobread shedrsquo, a place where he would create loaves upon loaves post-work and early in the morning, she says. ldquoHis magic little set-up was exactly what I had been looking for. It took a year for the trio and other family and friends to get the bakery open.I remark on how busy Aran is, and am informed it does some  transactions a day . The elongated Scottish tourist season means they are busy all year round rather than the traditional Easter to September.ldquoPeople have no idea how much work goes into this and how much we bake every single day, she says. A production kitchen on a small industrial park up the road in Birnam has helped alleviate the flow.So far, so impressive.But Irsquom intrigued.Alongside gorgeous recipes on how to make the goodies in the bakery ndash think Whisky Eccles cakes, pistachio and lime loaf, or butternut squash and Birnam honey loafndash her new book features little drop-in biogs of her regular customers and staff, many of them men, and also of her father. So the female vibe of her previous book, in which she praised the influence of women on home cooking, seems to have morphed into something more collegiate and collaborative ndash as well as less sugary-sweet. Aran follows a day in the le of the bakery, hour by hour and ritual by ritual, and there are recipes for sandwiches, salads, savoury tarts and sandwiches ndash and a heavy emphasis on sourdough breads, brioches and croissants.So, does running a bakery span the genders  ldquoYeah, it used to be all women but the balance is more even now. In fact, I call my team lsquoThe Boysrsquo, she says. ldquoGatherings was more focused on home and family whereas this is much bigger and wider in scope and people. What wersquore doing here is definitely more collaborative. People of both genders bring in ideas and suggestions, either orally or from memory, and we try them out. Wersquore doing continual RD and things are developing organically. And in the village, the wider community spirit is strong.She makes a point of sourcing ingredients, including the all-important flour, from the community and from Scotland as much as possible. Salmon is from the Dunkeld Smoke House, honey from master beekeeper John Taylor, and fresh produce is from the organic Dunkeld and Birnam Community Growing, known as The Field, and from Blackhall Farm. Butter is from Grahamrsquos Dairies, although her Lescure patisserie butter ndash good for croissants and pastries due to its high fat content ndash is from France. With Brexit in mind, she is looking for alternative local sources to provide her with the  kilos she goes through every week.ldquoThe really important thing for us is to be sustainable, she says.Her message about eating sensibly is also strong, and she cites the Rome-based food writer Rachel Roddy and the Irish writer Diana Henry as her food heroes for their ldquosensible approach to healthy eating.In Aran, she writes: ldquoSugar gets a bad rep, as does gluten, sadly. But my principles remain the same throughout this bizarre time. Use proper and honest ingredients and think of food as a source of fuel and satisfaction, not as something to fear or discuss negatively.Kale, which she says, ldquogets all the attention by the clean-eaters, and I worry it will put people off it, features strongly in her salad section alongside squash, carrot tops, heirloom tomatoes and asparagus. Therersquos a foraged nettle and pea quiche in a nod to Scottish culinary history and nettle pudding, ldquothe oldest recorded pudding in the book, but unlikely to make a reappearance.Her misgivings echo those expressed in the  Gatherings, in which she lamented the number of people of her age-group that she knew to have eating disorders or troubled relationships with food, and how ldquoearth-shattering that could be.The equal balance between sweet and savoury in Aran is notable, and again echoes the authorrsquos desire to change perceptions that baking is all about sweetness and stodge.Does she think her peer-group ndash at almost  she is somewhere between a Millennial and the younger so-called Generation Z ndash are confused about food and diet  ldquoYes, she replies, without hesitation. ldquoI am from the generation with arguably the most delusional approach to food. Therersquos so much noise surrounding it on social media. The influencer set are hugely to blame when it comes to diet issues. People arenrsquot sure about where they stand as they receive mixed messages almost every day.With veganism gaining in popularity among Gen Zedders, does she offer vegan options  ldquoA couple, but thatrsquos not something we do massively, she replies, with an almost imperceptible sigh. ldquoApart from the fact that itrsquos very hard to cater for every possible dietary requirement, our ethos here is hugely based on local, as opposed to dietary.ldquoTherersquos quite a contentious discourse about veganism. I think itrsquos doing more damage to the planet than eating dairy from the farm  miles down the road."As well as her concerns about food miles, she also has health worries. ldquoI think itrsquos crazy to eliminate so many food groups at once, as veganism advocates. Itrsquos about cutting out a huge amount of the foods wersquove been eating for thousands of years. Problems seem to have occurred with the processed foods wersquove had available for the last  years. Tradition has never done us any harm. Now everyonersquos terried about their health.Sipping milky tea and casting an eye over the ever-forming queue at the counter, she continues: ldquoIt makes me laugh when people come in to our bakery looking for gluten-free. But you can eat our sourdough bread because itrsquos slow-fermented for  hours, which reduces the gluten content dramatically, is more easily digested and therefore better for your gut. I spend a lot of time trying to tell people to try sourdough because itrsquos the best thing you can possibly eat.ldquoI tell them thatthey buy a supermarket loaf they should toast it before eating it to finish off the baking. Itrsquos over-processed and over-yeasted to bake in minutes rather than days and contains  ingredients instead of just three or four. When you eat it itrsquos going to keep cooking in your stomach and make you feel heavy and bloated. Bread should never feel heavy.ldquoEverything processed is why wersquove lost touch with fresh food. E-numbers, additives, colourants, preservatives and so on are all man-made and, of course, theyrsquore going to cause damage and health problems. Naturally occurring ingredients are hardly to blame.Traditional Scottish iced gingerbread, almond and pistachio croissants and chocolate brownies are her biggest sellers. ldquoItrsquos OK to have sugar in moderation. Little and often, she says, smiling. Her own favourites are the sourdough sandwiches made fresh every day and filled with locally sourced greenery. ldquoWe donrsquot do them to order, otherwise wersquod be making cheese and ham every day, she says, grinning.She already has her eyes on the future, and hopes to open a village greengrocers soon. ldquoWe want to stay in Dunkeld and open a village store where things will be properly sourced and we can support the local area, she says. ldquoAt the moment we can only buy plastic-wrapped apples from Spain at the local Co-op. Wersquod like to further help the local growers and producers, while completing the circular system in terms of sustainability, cutting food waste and increasing food security.She concedes that shersquos in the privileged position of being in the main street of a historic village which is popular with tourists with no large supermarkets or fast-food chains to dilute her influence. The local independent butcher, smokehouse, deli and whisky shop are hardly going to do that. In fact, she believes she is part of wider grassroots movement in Scotland that is being fed ndash and in turn consumed ndash by social media.The downside of being part of the Gen Z zeitgeist is she has in the past fallen foul of social mediarsquos more unpleasant side. A self-taught cook who grew up in Dunkeld, Shedden suffered a Twitter backlash when, as a contestant on GBBO, she said shersquod forgotten to switch on the electric oven because her parents had an Aga at home that she had over  cookbooks, most of them French and that she had picked up a recipe for biscotti while travelling in Italy. Such comments resulted in the Twittersphere posting that she was ldquotoo posh, ldquotoo middle-class and ldquotoo professional ndash comments that were picked up by the tabloids.She says now: ldquoI havenrsquot been on Twitter for months. I love Instagram, itrsquos a great way to communicate and a huge part of our business comes through it. It also helped us market our Crowdfunding campaign. It is about sharing. It is far more my vibe and less threatening than Twitter.ldquoThrough Instagram it never fails to amaze me how many fantastic wee independent food places, producers and initiatives there are right across Scotland now, she adds. ldquoI think people are a lot more aware of what theyrsquore eating and where their food comes from. They are aware of sourcing and what theyrsquore putting in their systems. Theyrsquore more interested in that than in price. I like to think that from our tiny part of the planet wersquore changing things bit by bit.Aran, Recipes and Stories from a Bakery in the Heart of Scotland, by Flora Shedden, is published by Hardie Grant at pound.BUTTERNUT SQUASH AND BIRNAM HONEYWe do our absolute best to source as many local ingredients as possible, and always encourage customers to come through the door with any of their own goods. One day, we received a wonky squash from a local gardener and a couple of jars of Birnam honey from a lovely man called Mark, and we knew we had to combine them. This is a mash-up of the only three recipes I could find that contained more butternut squash than sugarand the end result is quite unique. Not dissimilar to a tea cake, the crumb is very soft, and perfect with a cup of Lady Grey tea.Makes xgloafor a xxcmloaf gbutternut squash, peeledand roughly chopped sunflower oil, for roasting gunsalted butter gsoft brown sugar grunny honey egg gself-raising flour ggroundalmonds  golive oil ggolden raisinszest of  orangefrac teaspoon mixed spiceDemerara sugar, for scatteringPreheat the oven to C . Grease and line a loaf tin.Tip the squash into a roasting tin and drizzle with a little oil, but with no seasoning, which will feel bizarreyour roast a lot of veg. Cook for  minutes or until soft and tender ndash it doesnrsquot need to be too well coloured. We tend to roast a big batch, remove the amount needed for this recipe once cooked, then season the rest and use in salads. Let the squash cool down before blitzing to form a smooth pureacutee.In the bowl of a free-standing mixer, beat the butter, sugar and honey until smooth and pale. Add the egg, flour, almonds,using, and oil. Beat again until fully combined. Add the cooled pureacutee, raisins, zest and spice and mix together by hand. Pour into the prepared tin, sprinkle generously with Demerara sugar and bake for ndash minutes, or until cooked through and a kne inserted into the middle comes out clean.

title: scottish-council-leader-apologises-ram-yer-union-yer-hoop-tweet
story: John Ross, head of South Lanarkshire council, also posted images of a union jack flying from a pile of dog faeces, captioned with: ldquothe perfect answer to our unionist friends.The Hamilton South councillor posted the message after attending Saturdayrsquos independence rally in Glasgow, however it has drawn widespread criticism from opponents.:Former Scottish Premiership keeper to stand for Conservatives in general electionLiberal Democrat group leader Robert Brown and Labour group leader Joe Fagan have both criticised the SNP council leader for the tweet.Cllr Brown said: ldquoI really donrsquot know what Councillor Ross is thinking of in pushing these childish and offensive tweets on social media.ldquoSadly it is not the first time we have had such stuff from the SNP leader of South Lanarkshire Council.ldquoUnpleasant comments like this show an arrogance and contempt for the views of other people we can do without ndash people are already bitterly ided by the independence issue and by Brexit without senior SNP representatives stoking the fires of resentment and prejudice.ldquoJohn Ross should recognise the council leader represents everyone and stop being a cheerleader for the more unpleasant parts of his nationalist cause.Cllr Ross tweeted from his personal account and did not tweet in connection with his role as leader of South Lanarkshire Council.He has since deleted the tweet and apologised for sending it in the first place.I deleted a retweet from Saturdayrsquos Indy rally because I accept thatoffended some, it was not language I would normally use. I make no opology for holding the view that the UK is in a mess  Scotland would be better out of the union but I do apologise for any offence causedHe said: ldquoI was one of the thousands of people who took part in last weekendrsquos independence rally. My support for independence is well known, having been a member of the SNP since , and I am proud to be part of the campaign for another independence referendum.Mr Ross later deleted the tweet, but users were quick to screenshot itldquoIt is very clear to me that the UK is presently in a mess and that Scotland would be better off out of the Union, and that was the essence of the messages on the posters that I tweeted from the rally.:Stormzy blasts Jacob Rees-Mogg over dumb Grenfell tragedy commentsldquoHowever, the wording and images were not the sort of thing I would use myself and when I had a chance to reflect on this, I decided to delete the tweet from my timeline.ldquoI respect that other people may not share my political views and will be careful to take cognisance of this in any future tweets.ldquoI am fully committed to doing the best that I can for South Lanarkshire and all its residents, regardless of their political views or none. Certainly, I never intended to offend and my apologies go to anyone who was offended.All councillors are subject to the Standardrsquos Commission for Scotlandrsquos code of conduct and receive social media advice as part of training based on the code.South Lanarkshire Council declined to comment.

title: nicola-sturgeon-leaves-open-idea-dup-style-deal-labour
story: The First Minister has repeatedly rejected the idea of entering into any formal coalition with Jeremy Corbynhe fails to secure a majority on December .However, yesterday she did not rule out a looser, "confidence and supply arrangement in exchange for a second independence referendum.Following the  election, the DUP agreed to prop up Theresa Mayrsquos Government under such a deal, with the Northern Irish party supporting the Conservative administration on key issues.Asked on Sky News whether she would ldquodo a deal like the DUP on a confidence and supply basis, Ms Sturgeon said: ldquoWell, letrsquos see what the arithmetic is ndash there will be no formal coalition.She added: ldquoWe will see what the circumstances are. What I was about to go on to say is that I would favour more, and I think be more likely to end up in, a situation where we have an issue by issue arrangement where we support on some things and donrsquot support on others.ldquoBut wersquoll drive a hard bargain and wersquoll stand up for Scotlandrsquos interests, and wersquoll stand up for the kind of progressive values that people across the UK think are important and wersquoll want to see a very strong position on Brexit.It emerged earlier this week that Ms Sturgeon is set to enter into discussions with the UK civil service about her priorities in the event of any deal with Labour.These include a second independence referendum and the devolution of drug powers to Scotland.Whitehall officials can speak to opposition parties as part of a long-standing convention allowing them to prepare for a potential change in government.But last night, Labour shadow chancellor John McDonnell said: ldquoIf these reports are true then Nicola Sturgeon has been wasting her time. title: our-response-another-blaze-like-grenfell-different
story: Ms Cotton distanced the service from the stay-put policy which was criticised in the Grenfell Tower fire public inquiry while responding yesterday to questions at the London Assembly about the report into the fatal  blaze, which was released last week.ldquoKnowing what we know now about Grenfell Tower and similar buildings with ACM cladding, our response would be very dferent, the commissioner told the fire resilience and emergency planning committee. ldquoKnowing what we know now the actions that we would take would mean that we would respond in a dferent way.The fire chief told how the scale and magnitude of the fire in the -storey tower, which claimed  lives, had never been seen before in the UK.:Grenfell Tower tragedy -Systemic failures in fire brigades responseShe added that the brigade acknowledged all the recommendations made in the report and identied areas where training of its officers was ldquoinadequate.Ms Cotton said: ldquoWe have identied areas where our training was inadequate and where the information we collected was inadequate.ldquoWe do recognise there are areas where clearly there was insufficient training for both our firefighters, control staff and officers.The fire chief told the committee there were  fire engines at Grenfell and firefighters were there ldquoin number in a very short space of time.ldquoWe physically could not have put any more firefighters into the building at one time, she said, adding the single staircase in the tower limited the amount of personnel that could enter.Ms Cotton said that although there is now a greater understanding of how fires in buildings with cladding spread, it would be dficult to implement training to respond to such situations.ldquoBecause it is still such an extraordinary event of such a signicant scale we still have huge concerns, about the fires in those types of buildings.The commissioner was criticised last week when Sir Martin Moore-Bick found more lives could have been savedthe policy of telling residents to stay in their flats had been abandoned sooner.His report said there was an occasional reluctance of senior officers to believe that a building could ever fail to comply with regulations.The evidence from the first phase of the inquiry ldquostrongly suggests that ldquostay-put was an ldquoarticle of faith within the LFB so powerful that to depart from it was to all intents and purposes unthinkable, he said.Bereaved relatives of those who died in the fire have called on Ms Cotton to resign.Labour MP David Lammy, whose friend Khadija Saye and her mother Mary Mendy were among the victims, told the BBC that Ms Cotton should ldquotake ultimate responsibility, adding: ldquoLeadership was poor ndash coordination was poor. I think that in all decency some of what she said in inquiry was not just insensitive, it was sort of offensive.The next phase of the inquiry will focus on the installation of combustible cladding on the -storey tower block in .A group representing survivors of the blaze said the second phase of the public inquiry must focus on who is to blame for the towerrsquos ldquodevastating refurbishment.:Jacob Rees-Mogg apologises for Grenfell lsquocommon sensersquo commentsGrenfell United, which represents victims said: ldquoPhase two of the inquiry must now focus on where responsibility for the devastating refurbishment lies. The Royal Borough of Kensington and Cha, the tenant management organisation and all companies involved must face serious questions.Campaign group JusticeGrenfell said firefighters ldquohave been made scapegoats of Phase  while the lsquobigrsquo players seem to have got off scot-free.Sir Moore-Bick said: ldquoThe building suffered a total failure of compartmentation. How the building came to be in that state is the most pressing question ... in phase two.

title: red-deer-hinds-evolving-give-birth-earlier
story: Genetic changes in the red deer population on Rum have advanced their calving dates by around  days over the last  years.The findings, by a team of scientists from the universities of Edinburgh, St Andrews and Cambridge and the Australian National University, are thought to be some of the first evidence that wildle is evolving in response to changing environmental conditions.The discovery of the rapid sht in birth dates in recent years was made using field and genetic data collected from the Isle of Rum National Nature Reserve over a -year period.Dr Timotheacutee Bonnet, of the Australian National University, who led the study, said: ldquoThis is one of the few cases where we have documented evolution in action, showing that it may help populations adapt to climate warming.Previous studies have shown that the female deer, or hinds, have been giving birth earlier since the s, at a rate of around three days per decade, partly due to the effects of warmer temperatures on the deerrsquos behaviour and physiology.Mean maximum temperatures have increased at the rate of around . degrees per decade in the Hebrides, according to the research.Professor Josephine Pemberton, of the University of Edinburghrsquos school of biological sciences, said: ldquoLong-term studies of inidual letimes are one of the few ways to understand how populations respond to environmental change and how to manage its effects.The team notes what it terms ldquoplastic changes within the le of inidual hinds. They give birth to a single calf each year, and those that reproduce earlier in the year have more offspring over their letime.This is partly because of an association between the genes that causes the hinds to give birth earlier and higher overall reproductive success.As a result, genes for breeding earlier have become more common in the Rum red deer over time.Professor Pemberton said: ldquoWe are seeing hinds respond dferently during their letimes. A female that has a calf on a certain date in a cold year will have a calf on an earlier date following a warm summer. Something is changing that the animals are responding to and it seems to be the summer temperatures before the rut which is promoting grass growth.After a warm summer, the animals are coming into oestrus earlier, mating, conceiving and birthing earlier but after cold summers the findings were reversed, said Professor Pemberton.She said: ldquoSome of the changes wersquore seeing is because things are getting warmer and the animals are responding to that in their letimes, which wersquore calling plastic change.Traditionally the calving season has been from mid June but due to the altered environmental conditions, researchers have noted the season beginning as early as late May.The study also shows that the rutting season, antler casting and cleaning are all shting ndash and by a very similar time.The findings indicate that red deer could continue to thrive under changing weather: ldquoIn principle,the population can evolve, which is very strongly suggested by the data, then it will allow it to do well under changed environmental conditions.But more research on the impact of winter weather would need to be carried out to understand the final consequences of climate change.The study is unique in that it is teasing out the ious dferent causes of the calving changes, although researchers across the world are investigating how organisms are adapting to environmental change.Professor Pemberton said: ldquoThere has been a lot of discussion on whether animals are going to be able to change genetically and fast enough so this would be an indication that perhaps they will be able to.The research, published in the PLOS Biology journal, was funded by the Natural Environment Research Council.Sally Thomas, Scottish Natural Heritagersquos director of people and nature, said: ldquoThese findings are a fascinating example of the impact climate change may be having on wildle.ldquoMore and more research is demonstrating climate change is influencing species across the UK and the world. We are seeing growing evidence of the effects on Scotlandrsquos nature.ldquoSome species are finding it dficult to deal with changes, while others are moving northwards as conditions begin to change.

title: issue-day-george-michael-revival
story: A new song An unreleased track recorded prior to his death, titled This Is How , that Michael had been working on for his next album.Why now The song features in the upcoming movie, Last Christmas, which takes its name from the iconic festive track released by Wham! in , the duo that Michael formed at school with friend, Andrew Ridgeley.Whatrsquos the film about Co-written by Dame Emma Thompson - who also co-stars - it tells the tale of an unlucky young woman who accepts a job as a department store elf during the Christmas holidays.Michael gave his approval Prior to his death, Michael gave Thompson his blessing for the project that features three Wham songs!, as well as  solo tracks, including Wake Me Up Before You Go-Go, Everything She Wants and Praying For Time. Director Paul Feig ndash known for directing Bridesmaids and the Ghostbusters remake ndash said he was inspired to expand the soundtrack when he began to explore Michaels catalogue.And the song premieres today It gets its first play on Radio rsquos Zoe Ball Breakfast Show, ahead of the moviersquos release on November .Ball said: "I was, and am, a huge Wham! and George Michael fan and even though he is no longer with us, his music remains a joy to us all. Irsquom honoured to be premiering this previously unheard song from George on my Breakfast Show.What would George say Dame Emma believes the iconic singer - who sold more than  million records ndash would have loved the movie. She said: ldquoSo we lost him and I miss him so much. I wish he was here because I know hed love it, because the films like being hugged.ldquoThe wisdom and emotional scope of Georgersquos lyrics have always amazed me. So many feel like they were written for the movie.What did Michael die of The star ndash who had a turbulent personal le and was open about drug use ndash died of heart failure, having previously suffered serious health problems, including nearly dying after collapsing with pneumonia in .Now therersquos a campaign to get the song Last Christmas to number one Released in December , Last Christmas peaked at number  behind Band Aids Do They Know Its Christmas, which also featured Michael. His lawyer, Chris Organ, said it would be a ldquonice tributethe track hit number  this Christmas, saying: "Everyones going to be working very hard to make that happen," adding: ldquoGeorge was not only one of greatest British vocalists of all time, he was one of greatest British songwriters of all time.And whatrsquos the new song about Feig says it is ldquojust an absolutely amazing song that is ldquocelebratory.MAUREEN SUGDEN

title: aldi to trial reusable fresh produce bags
story: The Ellon and Inverurie Aldi stores will trial reusable bags for loose fruit and vegetables in an effort to cut single-use plastics.From the end of November the stores will offer the bags as a more sustainable alternative to single-use plastic.The drawstring bags are made from recycled plastic bottles and will be sold for p each.This is the supermarket’s latest step to reduce unnecessary plastic as it works towards reducing plastic packaging by % by the end of .If introduced nationally, the initiative will remove the equivalent of  tonnes of single-use plastic from circulation each year.Fritz Walleczek, Managing Director of Corporate Responsibility at Aldi, said: “We are committed to cutting the amount of plastic that Aldi and our customers use, particularly excess or single-use plastic like produce bags.“We are hopeful that our customers across Aberdeen and Aberdeenshire will embrace these new reusable produce bags whenever they’re buying loose fruit and veg and, together, we will be able to take more than  tonnes of plastic a year out of circulation.”data-src"https:images-e.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.ellontimes webimage ..! image image.jpg" class"article-suggested-teaser__image cld-responsive" alt"Drivers John Skinner, Ian Dixon and Ally Ferris promote free travel for all Veterans, Cadets and armed forces personnel for this years Remembrance Sunday events "  "  First Bus offers free journeys in honour of Remembrance Sunday viewBox"  . ." enable-background"new   . ." xml:space"preserve"c,,.-,.-.c-,-.,.-.C.,.,,,,.z"  Coremetrics  Coremetrics  Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventID  "ELLO | Article Teaser"Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventCatID  "ELLO | Article Teaser"

title: birds put on a show at forvie reserve
story: Photographers have captured stunning images of wild geese and waders flocking to a local nature reserve.Images taken at Scottish Natural Heritagenational nature reserve at Forvie reveal the mass migration of wild birds from Iceland, Greenland and Svalbard.Stuart MacQuarrie, SNH’s Head of Nature Reserves, said: “To see a flock of geese as they lt off from their night-time roost is one of Scotland’s greatest wildle spectacles. It’s such a remarkable aerial display, made even better by the chorus of their high-pitched calls.“These amazing birds migrate as far as , miles to reach Scotland for their winter feeding, before ing to more northern climes in the spring. And there’s plenty of time for people to come out to one of our nature reserves over the next few months and see this marvellous display for themselves.” At Forvie, there are about  waders, including  dferent species, on the Ythan estuary over autumn. There are good numbers of redshanks, lapwings, curlews, dunlins, golden plovers and oyster catchers. An occasional rarity also shows up at Forvie, this year including a great egret, ten common cranes – and a terek sandpiper, only the second ever spotted in North East Scotland and the th in Scotland.The best places to watch them are from the hide at Waulkmill or the two laybys that overlook the estuary north of Newburgh on the A, where you can use your car as a hide and watch the undisturbed birds. There are also good views to be had by parking at theWaterside car parkand walking down the north side of the river on the Dune Trail.SNH’s Forvie reserve manage, David Pickett, explains:“These fantastic viewpoints make the Ythan one of the most accessible birdwatching spots in Scotland for waders.The best time to watch these amazing birds is approaching high tide, as the water is moving the birds closer to you.”For more info about Forvie nature reserve see:www.nnr-scotland.org.uk.data-src"https:images-o.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.inverurieherald webimage ..! image image.jpg" class"article-suggested-teaser__image cld-responsive" alt"Engineers installing the two concrete shafts"  Progress at Kintore rail station site viewBox"  . ." enable-background"new   . ." xml:space"preserve"c,,.-,.-.c-,-.,.-.C.,.,,,,.z"  Coremetrics  Coremetrics  Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventID  "INVE | Article Teaser"Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventCatID  "INVE | Article Teaser"

title: expansion plans set to boost kintore businesses
story: Two Kintore-based businesses are set to more than double in size and create around  jobs with ambitious six-figure expansion plans.Husband and we team, James and Rebecca Carr, who run Kintore Car Sales and Rebecca Carr Hair Salon, are expanding both businesses to enhance their offering in the area.Mr Carr has moved his car sales and valeting firm to a two-acre site adjacent to his other facility which has quadrupled the size of his business footprint, allowing him to add a new servicing ision to the business.The move has already seen the headcount increase to five with plans to double staff numbers to support the continuing expansion of the seven-year-old business.Mrs Carr, who launched her salon in  which has  employees and more than , clients, is set to expand into a purpose-designed, sq ft building on the site of the previous car sales courtyard, in addition to continuing to operate her current salon in the village’s Midmill Parade.The new venture, Rebecca Carr Residence, will add a beauty lounge to the services, with the venue set to include private beauty rooms, in addition to pedicure stations, a nail and brow bar, make-up artist station and a retail gt section.The ‘Residence’ will also boast a café with outdoor space which will be run by fellow local business, From Bakery Lane, and will also boast private customer parking.The renovation, which is due to complete by November, will more than double the size of Mrs Carr’s business and create a further  jobs in the village.The couple, who also live in the village, are committed to investing in title: first bus offers free journeys in honour of remembrance sunday
story: Bus operator First Bus is providing free travel to all armed forces personnel, veterans and cadets travelling to services and events across Scotland for Remembrance Sunday .All armed forces personnel, veterans and cadets showing their unorm and badges, or a recognised ID badge, can claim free travel up to pm on Sunday as they travel to and from Remembrance Day activities. The concession by one of Scotland’s biggest bus operator is in honour of all the fallen and the surviving veterans of conflict and it means that services across all three operating companies in First Aberdeen, First Glasgow and First Scotland East will be honouring the offer.Andrew Jarvis, Managing Director of First Scotland, said: “Remembrance Sunday is an important and solemn reminder of the sacrices made by so many in our Armed Forces and we wanted to do something to mark the occasion.“We have a number of veterans working for First Bus across all of our Scotland depots and we are very proud of their efforts and sacrice, so this is our way of saying thank you to them as well as honouring all men and women who choose to serve and protect the freedoms our country now takes for granted.“We hope this concession on our services will make it as easy as possible for as many Veterans, Armed Forces personnel and cadets to attend the ious Remembrance services and events up and down the country on Sunday to mark the occasion.”Gordon Michie, the head of fundraising at Poppyscotland, added: “Remembrance Sunday is an important moment in the national psyche. This is especially so for those who have selflessly served in our Armed Forces, many of whom have friends who have made the ultimate sacrice.“Providing free travel to veterans to help them attend Remembrance Sunday events across the country is a wonderful gesture by First Group and we commend them for this, and for their ongoing commitment to the Armed Forces community.”data-src"https:images-o.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.inverurieherald webimage ..! image image.jpg" class"article-suggested-teaser__image cld-responsive" alt"Bonfire Night is the busiest night of the year for the Scottish Fire and Rescue Service." story: Garioch Sports Centre in Inverurie has announced they are adding a Family Membership to their existing offering.The new membership will be available as a Black Friday deal throughout the month of November as part of Garioch Sports Centre’s ‘Black November’ initiative.The membership will launch on Friday, November  and will be available to purchase until Saturday, November .Kevin Bonarius, Chief Operating Officer, said: "Our Family Membership has been a long time coming. We’re proud to be more than just a gym, we’re a family facility and that’s at the heart of everything we do."Our Family Membership incorporates the very best from our existing fitness memberships coupled with kids and teens activities too."Families will be able to enjoy gym access, unlimited access to over  fitness class each week, teen gym and kid’s activities alongside reduced rates for personal training, creche, court hire and all of the benefits of GSCrewards – our new member benefit scheme."Kevin added: "Our Family Membership is a cost-effective way for families to stay active and enjoy exercise together.
